choices.text: Continue atenolol till the day of surgery

questions.text: A 68 years old hypertensive and diabetic from last 5 years on regular medication atenolol 40mg, atorvastatin 20mg and metformin 40mg. Which is incorrect statement regarding perioperative medication management?
questions.solution:
Atenolol is a antihypertensive medication, which is continued till the day of surgery and metformin, a hypoglycaemic agent is stopped.

Perioperative Medication management:

  1. Antihypertensives: continued till the day of surgery
  2. Oral hypoglycaemics: for minor surgeries stop the last dose, but for major surgeries we stop the last dose and put the patient on insulin.
  3. Steroids continue them with perioperative supplementation
  4. Anti epileptics, antipsychotics, antidepressants are continued with exceptions, like TCA is stopped 3 weeks prior and lithium, 1 day prior to surgery
  5. Aspirin is continued
    • Clopidogrel - stop 4 to 5 days prior to surgery
    • LMWH - stop 12 hours prior to surgery
    • Warfarin - 3 to 4 days prior to surgery

questions.text: Pseudo koebner's phenomenon is seen in?
questions.solution:
Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon is the development of new lesion along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. This new lesion have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

Pseudo - Koebner phenomenon is appearance of similar lesions around the original lesion due to autoinoculation caused by trauma

Option a, b, c shows true Koebner's phenomena.

Tag: Signs in dermatology

Reference: Sanchez DP, Sonthalia S. Koebner phenomenon.

questions.text:
A patient with pneumonia presents with hyponatremia and other electrolyte imbalances. The Gram stain image shows a poor Gram stain result with slender, Gram-negative rods, best identified by special stains or culture methods.

Which bacterial pathogen is most likely causing this pneumonia?
questions.solution:
• Gram Negative rod, stains poorly, hence silver stain is used. Grow on charcoal yeast extract medium with iron and cysteine. Detected by presence of antigen in urine. Labs may show hyponatremia and elevated transaminases.
  • Aerosol transmission from environmental water source (eg, air conditioning systems, hot water tanks). Outbreaks associated with cruise ships, nursing homes. No person-to-person transmission.
  • Treatment: macrolide or quinolone

Explanation:

A) Legionella pneumophila: Slender, Gram-negative rods that may not be well-stained by Gram stain; best identified by special stains or culture.

B) Mycoplasma pneumoniae: Lacks a cell wall, so does not gram stain well; diagnosed by other methods.

C) Chlamydia pneumoniae: Intracellular pathogen, does not stain well with Gramstain.

D) Streptococcus pneumoniae: Gram-positive diplococci, not slender rods.

Key Takeaway: Legionella pneumophila is identified by its slender, Gram-negative rods and requires special stains or culture for definitive identification.

Reference: CDC Legionnaire's Disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with decreased vision and photophobia in both eyes, several months after undergoing surgical repair for a penetrating injury in the right eye. On examination, bilateral anterior uveitis with signs of vitritis and choroiditis are observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sympathetic ophthalmia

  • Bilateral, granulomatous uveitis that occurs after trauma or surgery to one eye, leading to inflammation in the uninjured, or "sympathetic", eye.
  • It is an autoimmune response where the immune system attacks the uveal tissue of the unaffected eye following trauma to the other eye.

Etiology: Typically occurs after ocular trauma (e.g., penetrating injury) or ocular surgery. The exact mechanism is unclear but is believed to involve a hypersensitivity reaction to uveal antigens that are released from the injured eye and then recognized as foreign by the immune system.

Clinical Features:

  • Onset: Can occur weeks to months after the initial trauma or surgery.
  • Symptoms in Affected Eye:
    • Decreased vision
    • Redness
    • Pain
    • Photophobia
    • Floaters
  • Signs:
    • Bilateral uveitis (both anterior and posterior segments may be involved)
    • Vitritis (inflammation of the vitreous body)
    • Choroiditis (inflammation of the choroid)
    • Retinal edema
    • Possible optic nerve involvement

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Examination: Comprehensive eye examination showing bilateral uveitis with characteristic findings of sympathetic ophthalmia.
  • Imaging: OCT (Optical Coherence Tomography) and fundus photography may be used to assess retinal and choroidal involvement.
  • Exclusion of Other Causes: Important to rule out other causes of bilateral uveitis and intraocular inflammation.

Management:

  • Immediate Treatment: High-dose systemic corticosteroids are typically used to reduce inflammation and prevent further damage.
  • Additional Immunosuppressive Therapy: May be necessary for cases resistant to corticosteroids or to reduce the steroid dose.
  • Supportive Care: Includes managing symptoms and monitoring for complications.

Prognosis: With prompt and aggressive treatment, vision can often be preserved. However, if untreated, sympathetic ophthalmia can lead to significant visual impairment or blindness.

Complications: Include chronic uveitis, retinal detachment, and vision loss.

  • Option B) Sympathetic Ophthalmia: This condition is characterized by bilateral granulomatous uveitis occurring after trauma or surgery to one eye. The patient's history of ocular trauma followed by bilateral uveitis and vitritis aligns with this diagnosis.
  • Option A) Acute Anterior Uveitis: Typically unilateral and more associated with a specific etiology rather than a delayed onset after ocular trauma.
  • Option C) Herpes Simplex Keratitis: Generally presents with dendritic ulcers on the cornea and is not typically associated with bilateral uveitis after trauma.
  • Option D) Behcet's Disease: A systemic vasculitis that can cause bilateral uveitis, but is usually accompanied by other systemic symptoms such as oral and genital ulcers

Reference: Parson's Diseases of the Eye, 22nd Edition, Section VI, Chapter 15, pg. 349

questions.text: A 33 year individual sustained injury to right arm while driving 2 wheeler. Xray showed lower third humerus shaft fracture. He also has wrist drop and EMG-NCV shows findings consistent with neuroma in continuity. Classify the nerve injury according to Seddon's classification.
questions.solution:
Radial nerve injury is a common complication in distal third humeral shaft fractures. There notorious fractures are known as Holstien-Lewis fractures.

There are 2 classification systems for nerve injuries.

  • Seddon's classification divides them in 3 categories namely neuropraxia, axonotmesis and neurotmesis.
  • Sunderland classification further divides axonotmesis type injury into further three categories making 5 categories in total as shown in the table.

Neuroma in continuity - If the endoneural tube is interrupted, the sprouts, as many as 100 from one axonal stump, may migrate aimlessly throughout the damaged area into the epineural, perineural or adjacent tissues to form an end-neuroma or a neuroma in continuity. Axonotmesis involves only axonal cut sparing the outer sheath, so when axonal sprouts occur, neuroma in continuity is formed. An end-neuroma may form when the proximal-end is widely separated from the distal-end which is possible in neurotmesis. A Side neurons usually indicates a partial nerve cut.

Reference: Miler's, 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 1532

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for FNAC?
questions.solution:
Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) is a diagnostic procedure used to extract cells from a mass for examination under a microscope. While it is generally considered safe, there are some contraindications to its use.

Absolute Contraindications:

  1. Uncorrected bleeding disorders: FNAC should be avoided in patients with significant coagulopathies or uncorrected bleeding disorders (e.g., hemophilia, thrombocytopenia) due to the risk of hemorrhage.
  2. Unstable vascular lesions: Vascular lesions like aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) should not be aspirated as puncturing them can result in catastrophic bleeding.
  3. Infection at the puncture site: If the skin or surrounding tissues at the aspiration site are infected (e.g., cellulitis, abscess), FNAC can worsen the infection or cause it to spread.

Relative Contraindications:

  1. Lack of a safe pathway: In cases where a clear, safe pathway to the mass is not available, such as with deep-seated lesions near major blood vessels or vital structures, FNAC should be done under imaging guidance or avoided.
  2. Suspected vascular tumors: Tumors with a highly vascular nature, like hemangiomas, should be approached with caution as they may bleed during or after the procedure.
  3. Patients on anticoagulant therapy: While anticoagulation therapy is not an absolute contraindication, special precautions should be taken. In some cases, stopping the anticoagulation or bridging with another therapy may be necessary.
  4. Very small or cystic lesions: In cases of small lesions or cystic structures, FNAC may not yield sufficient diagnostic material, which can limit the utility of the procedure.
  5. Poor patient cooperation: FNAC requires the patient to remain still during the procedure. Uncooperative patients, such as those with mental or neurological conditions, may pose a challenge, and sedation may be required.

Explanation:

  1. Bleeding disorders, such as hemophilia or thrombocytopenia, increase the risk of excessive bleeding during FNAC.
  2. Pregnancy is not a contraindication for FNAC, but caution should be taken.
  3. Previous surgery at the site is not a contraindication, but may affect the accuracy of the results.
  4. Age > 60 years is not a contraindication for FNAC.

KEY TAKEAWAYS - The risks and benefits of performing FNAC should be carefully weighed, and alternative diagnostic methods may be considered if the risks are too high.

Reference: Orell & Streertt's fnac, 5th edition, Page no.10.

choices.text: It is easier to observe inverse agonism if there is sufficient constitutive activity of receptor in the absence of agonist.
An inverse agonist has a higher affinity for the active form of receptor as compared to the inactive form.
If the equilibrium of receptor states lies in the direction of inactive conformation in the absence of a ligand, it may be impossible to demonstrate inverse agonism.
Famotidine and losartan can be considered inverse agonists.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate feature regarding inverse agonism?
questions.solution:
• In pharmacology, an inverse agonist is an agent which binds to the same receptor binding-site as an agonist for that receptor and reverses constitutive activity of receptors.
  • Inverse agonists exert the opposite pharmacological effect of a receptor agonist.
  • Inverse agonists have affinity but intrinsic activity with a minus sign (IA between 0 and -1).
  • Inverse agonism is manifest only in case of some receptors which show certain degree of Constitutive activation, i.e. they are partially active even in the basal state (complete absence of any agonist).
  • Inverse agonists are effective against certain types of receptors (e.g. certain histamine receptors and GABA receptors) which have intrinsic activity without the action of a ligand upon them (also referred to as 'constitutive activity'.)

B. They both have the same affinity

C. Its possible to demonstrate

D. Losartan and Famotidine are antagonists

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 50

questions.text: A young male with a history of drug abuse is brought to casualty in an altered state. His 8-year-old sister has ADHD. His parents show an empty pill bottle that he might have taken. Which of the following is likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient with a substance abuse history and access to ADHD medication now probably has stimulant intoxication. He is most likely to have tachycardia.
  • Methylphenidate, dextroamphetamine, and dextroamphetamine/amphetamine combination products are stimulant medications that are used for the treatment of ADHD in children. These drugs are often used by drug abusers.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man had surgery while being intubated. The most effective way to verify the location of the endotracheal tube is:
questions.solution:
The most important and objective indicator of tracheal intubation, however, is the presence of a normal capnogram (carbon dioxide [CO2] waveform) for the presence of at least three breaths. Severe bronchospasm, equipment malfunction, cardiac arrest, or hemodynamic collapse may prevent the appearance of a capnogram tracing despite proper ETT placement.

In patients with adequate tissue perfusion, assess and confirm the location of the endotracheal tube using an end-tidal carbon dioxide detector (such as continuous waveform capnography, colorimetric capnography, or non-waveform capnography). Signs of correct endotracheal intubation:

  1. Detection of ETCO2 by Capnography (Surest confirmation)
  2. Bilaterally auscultated breath sounds
  3. Symmetric chest rise
  4. Absence of epigastric breath sound
  5. Visible mist in the ET tube
  6. Large exhaled Tidal volume
  7. Good compliance of reservoir bag during manual ventilation
  8. Fiberoptic bronchoscope - best method for double lumen ETT

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1308, 1309, 1392-1398.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is used to assess an individual's intraoperative awareness?
questions.solution:
• BIS is a monitoring technique used to check the depth of anesthesia and assess intraoperative awareness.
  • It processes the EEG and provides an index value between 0 and 100 that indicates the patient's level of consciousness.
  • Pulse oximetry is used for monitoring O2 saturation.
  • Color doppler is an ultrasonographic method
  • EtCO2 is a graphic representation used for circulation, ventilation and metabolism

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1282.

questions.text: A 3 year old male patient presented with skin lesions as shown. What complication can arise from it
questions.solution:
Erosions in the perioral and perinasal areas typically covered in golden honey crusts suggest it is non bullous impetigo. The main organism responsible for this condition is streptococcus pyogenes.

Option a and b are caused by streptococcus but non bullous impetigo will not progress towards ARF.

ARF can only occur as a consequence of either pharyngitis or tonsillitis only but never from impetigo.

Impetigo is of 2 types

  • Non bullous impetigo
  • Bullous impetigo

Treatment

  • Topical mupirocin
  • Oral antibiotics

questions.text: A 35 year old patient with multiple lesions on the body as shown below. which of the following is not a histological feature of the disease?
questions.solution:
Well defined red plaques with a silvery white scale suggests it is a case of psoriasis.

Munro Micro abscess, spongiform pustules of Kogoj, and Hypogranulosis are histological features of psoriasis

Option a - Max Joseph space is a histology feature of lichen planus not psoriasis.

Elongated camel foot rete ridges

Saw tooth rete ridges

questions.text: A patient was brought to emergency with history of intake of some unknown seeds. He had convulsions, opisthotonus and facial muscle spasm. The most likely poisoning is with:
questions.solution:
Signs and symptoms resemble poisoning due to nux vomica seeds.

Signs and symptoms are seen within 15-30 minutes of ingestion. A 'conscious' seizure is the characteristic presentation of strychnine poisoning.

Findings associated with poisoning are

  1. Bitter taste.
  2. Choking sensation in throat, and stiffness of the neck and face.
  3. Prodromal symptoms: Restlessness, increased acuity of perception, increased rigidity of muscles and muscular twitchings.
  4. Face: Cyanosed, look is anxious, eyes are staring, eyeballs are prominent, and the pupils are dilated. Mouth is filled with bloodstained froth.
  5. Convulsions: The threshold for CNS stimulation is lowered with the result that any sensory stimulus (light, pain, touch, or noise) may produce violent muscular spasm. Initially, clonic but eventually become tonic, and affect all the muscles at the same time.
  • Risus sardonicus results from raising of patient's eyebrows, bulging of eyes and contraction of the jaw and facial muscles in which the corners of the mouth are drawn back leading to an evil looking grin. This expression can be seen in tetanus too.
  • Convulsions are more marked in anti-gravity muscles resulting in hyperextension (opisthotonos)
  • Sometimes, the spasm of the abdominal muscles may bend the body forward (emprosthotonus) or sideways (pleurosthotonus).
  • Duration of convulsions is about half to 2 min and may recur for 12-24 hours (h). During convulsions the patient remains awake and aware of everything around him since strychnine does not cross the blood-brain barrier.
  • In between convulsions, muscles are completely relaxed and breathing is resumed. Patient is usually in pain, exhausted, anxious and anticipating the next series of convulsions.
  • After 5-15 min, on the slightest impulse, such as sudden noise, current of air or on gently touching the patient, another convulsion occurs with increased intensity.
  • Increased muscle tone, hyperreflexia, agitation, restlessness and convulsions lead to profound lactic acidosis, rhabomyolysis and hyperthermia.
  • Death occurs within 4-5 convulsions as the patient cannot breathe. Consciousness is not lost and the mind remains clear till death. At the time of death, the body 'freezes' even in the middle of convulsions resulting in 'cadaveric spasm.

Cause of death: Death is due to medullary paralysis or asphyxia due to spasm of respiratory muscles or due to exhaustion from convulsions.

Reference: Review of Forensic medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 5th edition, Page No. 630

questions.text:
A patient presents with a skin lesion that has a black eschar. The Gram stain image shows large, Gram-positive rods with square ends and a characteristic "boxcar" appearance.

Which bacterial species is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Gram-positive rods with a "boxcar" appearance and large size, associated with cutaneous anthrax and a black eschar.

A) Bacillus anthracis: Gram-positive rods with a "boxcar" appearance and large size, associated with cutaneous anthrax and a black eschar.

B) Bacillus cereus: Gram-positive rods but not with the characteristic "boxcar" appearance.

C) Clostridium botulinum: Gram-positive rods but typically associated with botulism, not the "boxcar" appearance.

D) Clostridium perfringens: Gram-positive rods but typically associated with gas gangrene, not the "boxcar" appearance.

Key Takeaway: Bacillus anthracis is characterized by large, Gram-positive rods with a "boxcar" appearance, often associated with cutaneous anthrax.

Reference: CDC Bacillus anthracis

questions.text:
A patient with recent antibiotic use presents with severe diarrhea. The stool sample shows Gram-positive, rod-shaped bacteria with spores.

Which bacterial pathogen is most likely causing the symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Produces toxins A and B, which damage enterocytes. Both toxins lead to watery diarrhea- pseudomembranous colitis.
  • Often 2°to antibiotic use, especially clindamycin, ampicillin, cephalosporins, fluoroquinolones; associated with PPIs.
  • Causes Fulminant infection: toxic megacolon, ileus, shock.

A) Clostridium difficile: Gram-positive rods with spores, commonly associated with antibiotic-associated diarrhea, pseudo membranous colitis.

B) Clostridium tetani: Gram-positive rods but not typically spore-forming in stool samples.

C) Bacillus cereus: Gram-positive rods, but not primarily associated with spore-forming diarrhea.

D) Bacillus anthracis: Gram-positive rods, but associated with anthrax rather than diarrhea.

Key Takeaway: Clostridium difficile is identified by its Gram-positive, spore-forming rods, especially in the context of recent antibiotic use.

Reference: CDC Clostridium difficile

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and a palpable mass after undergoing a Caesarean section. Imaging reveals a rectus sheath hematoma. Which artery is most likely the source of bleeding in this case?
questions.solution:
OPTION B: Inferior epigastric artery: It runs along the posterior surface of the rectus abdominis muscle and is a common source of bleeding in a rectus sheath hematoma post-Caesarean section. It can be injured during the incision or suturing of the lower abdominal wall.

OPTION A: Superior epigastric artery: This artery is a continuation of the internal thoracic artery and supplies the upper part of the rectus abdominis muscle. It is less likely to be injured in a Caesarean section, which is performed in the lower abdomen.

OPTION C: External iliac artery: It is located deeper in the pelvis and supplies the lower limbs. It is not typically involved in a rectus sheath hematoma.

OPTION D: Deep circumflex iliac artery: This artery supplies the iliac region and is not usually implicated in rectus sheath hematomas resulting from Caesarean sections.

Type: Must know

Topic: Caesarean section

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Page no. 55

During delivery, a tear is noted to extend through the vaginal mucosa, perineal muscles, and involves the external anal sphincter. Rectal mucosa is uninvolved. What degree of perineal tear is most likely in this case?

SULTAN'S CLASSIFICATION OF PERINEAL TEARS

Type: Must know

Topic: Perineal Tears

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Page no. 1275-1276

questions.text: Which of the following types of staphyloma commonly associated with high myopia?
questions.solution:
Types of staphyloma:

  1. Posterior Staphyloma
    • Location: Posterior pole of the eye
    • Associated Conditions: High myopia, degenerative conditions
    • Description: Localized protrusion at the back of the eye, often linked to high myopia and scleral thinning.
  2. Equatorial Staphyloma
    • Location: Equator of the eye
    • Associated Conditions: Myopia, scleral degeneration
    • Description: Outpouching around the equatorial region, characterized by scleral thinning and bulging.
  3. Anterior Staphyloma
    • Location: Anterior part of the eye
    • Associated Conditions: Corneal ectasia, thinning
    • Description: Protrusion at the front of the eye, associated with corneal thinning or ectasia.
  4. Intermediate Staphyloma
    • Location: Between anterior and posterior poles
    • Associated Conditions: Rare conditions
    • Description: A less common type occurring between the anterior and posterior poles, often with less specific characteristics.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Section 5, Chapter 18, pg. 467

#posterior staphyloma #anterior staphyloma #July 2021 FMGE

choices.text: Compressive neuropathy of superficial branch of radial nerve
Compressive neuropathy of lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
Compressive neuropathy of ulnar digital nerve

questions.text: Select true statement about Cheralgia paresthetica:
questions.solution:
Cheralgia Paresthetica (Wartenberg Syndrome)

  • Definition:
    • Compressive neuropathy of the Superficial Branch of the Radial Nerve (SBRN) (Option A)
  • Cause:
    • Nerve compression occurs between the brachioradialis and Extensor Carpi Radialis Longus (ECRL) with forearm pronation.
    • Compression results from a scissor-like action between the tendons.
  • Presentation:
    • Symptoms include pain, numbness, and paresthesias over the dorsoradial hand.
    • Difficulty wearing a watch or jewellery due to pain over the nerve.
  • Provocative Tests:
    • Forceful forearm pronation for 60 seconds.
    • Tinel test.
  • Nonoperative Treatment:
    • Activity modification.
    • Splinting.
    • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).
  • Surgical Decompression:
    • Considered if a 6-month trial of nonoperative treatment fails.

Option B - Compressive neuropathy of median nerve is called carpal tunnel syndrome.

Option C- Compressive neuropathy of lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is called meralgia paresthetica.

Option D- Compressive neuropathy of ulnar digital nerve is called bowler's thumb

Reference: Miler's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 1531

questions.text:
A 44 year individual sustained a road traffic accident and was diagnosed to have Maisonneuve fracture in left lower limb. Choose the possible outcomes of this particular injury from given options.
1. Fibula neck fracture is usually missed
2. Medial malleolus fracture united well conservatively
3. May result in CPN injury and foot drop
4. Can cause dorsalis pedis artery injury
questions.solution:
1. Fibula neck fracture is usually missed

3. May result in CPN injury and foot drop

Maisonneuve fracture - It is a type of ankle fracture in which fracture of medial malleolus occur as well as with fracture of the neck of the fibula.

Statement 1 - As the pain is usually in the ankle region the fracture of fibula neck is usually missed

Statement 2 - It cannot be be treated conservatively due to risk of nonunion.

We must do open reduction and screw fixation.

Statement 3 - CPN palsy and foot drop post fibula neck fracture is a common.

Statement 4 - The injured structure is common peroneal nerve.

Maisonneuve Injury

  • Definition:
    • High-energy leg injury involving fibular fracture and syndesmotic ligament damage.
  • Mechanism of Injury:
    • Twisting or rotational force applied to the leg.
    • Common in sports or accidents.
  • Key Components:
    • Fibular Fracture: Typically proximal (near the knee).
    • Syndesmotic Injury: Damage to the ligament connecting tibia and fibula.
    • Associated Injuries: May include ankle fractures or dislocations.
  • Symptoms:
    • Severe lower leg pain.
    • Swelling and bruising.
    • Difficulty bearing weight.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Physical examination.
    • X-rays for bone fractures and alignment.
    • MRI or CT scan for soft tissue and syndesmotic injury.
  • Treatment:
    • Nonoperative: Rest, immobilization, physical therapy if stable.
    • Operative: Surgery for realignment and stabilization if severe.
  • Prognosis:
    • Generally good with appropriate treatment; rehabilitation is key for recovery.

Reference: Koval's Handbook of fractures' 5th edition, page no. 442

questions.text: A 60 year old male presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and hepatomegaly. Imaging studies reveal a large, heterogeneous liver mass. Biopsy confirms Hepatic Angiosarcoma. All of the following exposures are associated with this except?
questions.solution:
Hepatic angiosarcoma is a rare and aggressive primary malignant tumor of the liver that originates from endothelial cells lining blood vessels.

Several environmental and chemical exposures have been associated with an increased risk:

  1. Thorium dioxide (Thorotrast): Historically used as a contrast agent in radiology, it has been linked to a high incidence of hepatic angiosarcoma.
  2. Vinyl chloride: A chemical used in the production of plastics has been strongly associated with hepatic angiosarcoma.
  3. Arsenic: Chronic exposure to arsenic has been implicated in the development of hepatic angiosarcoma.
  4. Anabolic steroids: Long-term use of anabolic steroids may increase the risk.
  5. Hemochromatosis: Some reports suggest an association between hepatic angiosarcoma and hereditary hemochromatosis, a condition characterized by excess iron storage in the liver.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Hepatic Angiosarcoma is a rare, aggressive liver cancer often associated with variety of carcinogenic exposures including Arsenic(A), Thorotrast(B) and poly vinyl chloride(D).

Iron dose not have any role in causing hepatic angiosarcoma.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO.522.

choices.text: To check mitotic damage in cell due to radiation
To permit cells to enter quiescence
To regulate cell growth and division

questions.text: What is the primary function of the G1 checkpoint in the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
The G1 checkpoint ensures that a cell is ready to enter the S phase of the cell cycle by checking:

  1. Cell Size: Ensures the cell has grown enough to divide.
  2. DNA Integrity: Detects and repairs DNA damage or triggers apoptosis if the damage is irreparable.
  3. Nutrient Availability: Confirms sufficient nutrients and energy are present.
  4. Growth Signals: Responds to external growth factors needed for division.
  5. Quiescence Decision: Determines whether to proceed or enter a resting state (G0).

Key regulators include p53 (DNA damage response), Cyclins/CDKs, and Retinoblastoma (Rb). If conditions are favourable, the cell moves into the S phase for DNA replication.

D. The G1 checkpoint ensures that cells are ready to enter the S phase and undergo DNA replication by checking for proper cell growth and division.

A. Checking mitotic damage in cell due to radiation is the function of G2-M checkpoint.

B. Chromosome segregation occurs during mitosis phase.

C. Quiescence is a state of dormancy that can occur outside of the cell cycle in G0 phase

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The G1 checkpoint ensures that cells are ready to enter the S phase and undergo DNA replication by checking for proper cell growth and division.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS AND COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 27.

questions.text: Of the following, which will not be blocked by atropine and scopolamine?
questions.solution:
• ACh will stimulate both muscarinic and nicotinic receptors.
  • Skeletal muscle contraction is mediated through NM receptors, and ganglionic stimulation is an effect of NN receptors.
  • All of the other effects listed in the question occur following muscarinic receptor activation and will be blocked by atropine and scopolamine, both of which are muscarinic receptor antagonists
  • Skeletal muscle contraction will not be affected by these drugs; rather, a neuromuscular blocker (e.g., tubocurarine) is required to antagonize this effect of ACh.

ANTICHOLINERGIC DRUGS

  • These drugs act by blocking muscarinic (anti-muscarinic) or nicotinic receptors.
  • Drugs blocking NM receptors are called neuromuscular blocking agents and those blocking NN receptors are called ganglion blockers.
  • Atropine (obtained from Atropa belladonna) and scopolamine (l-hyoscine) are natural alkaloids that act as non-selective antagonists at all muscarinic receptors.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 125-126

questions.text: A 67 year old male patient came to emergency department with history of consuming 20 tablets of beta blocker group of medicine. His presenting features were excessive bradycardia with decrease in cardiac output. Which of the following agent is least likely to be useful for treatment of beta blocker induced excessive bradycardia with decrease in cardiac output?
questions.solution:
• Phentolamine being a non-selective α receptor blocker, it will lead to hypotension because of dilatation of blood vessels hence not useful agent for β adrenergic receptor antagonists poisoning

β adrenergic receptor antagonists poisoning

  • The manifestations of poisoning with β adrenergic receptor antagonists depend on the pharmacological properties of the ingested drug, particularly its β1 selectivity, intrinsic sympathomimetic activity, and membrane-stabilizing properties.
  • Hypotension, bradycardia, prolonged AV conduction times, and widened QRS complexes are common manifestations of overdosage.
  • Seizures and depression may occur. Hypoglycemia and bronchospasm can occur.
  • Significant bradycardia should be treated initially with atropine, but a cardiac pacemaker often is required.
  • Large doses of α adrenergic receptor agonist may be necessary to treat hypotension.
  • Glucagon, acting through its own GPCR and independently of the β adrenergic receptor, has positive chronotropic and inotropic effects on the heart, and the drug has been useful in some patients who have an overdose of a β receptor antagonist.

Drugs useful in beta blocker toxicity/Bradycardia:

  • Atropine
  • Isproterenol
  • Glucagon
  • Dopamine & Dobutamine
  • Epinephrine/norepinephrine

Glucagon increases the force and rate of cardiac contraction and this is not antagonized by β blockers.

Uses of Glucagon:

  1. Hypoglycaemia
  • Use of glucagon to counteract insulin/ oral hypoglycaemic drug induced hypoglycaemia is only an expedient measure for the emergency, and must be followed by oral glucose/sugar given repeatedly till the blood glucose level stabilizes
  1. Cardiogenic shock
  • Glucagon may be used to stimulate the heart in β adrenergic blocker treated patients.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 304

questions.text: A 35-year-old man complained of low mood, decreased appetite, and loss of weight for the past 2 months. He mentions that he feels worthless and has decreased interest in activities. He also complains of great difficulty falling asleep. He has past history of atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs should be preferred for this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient in the given clinical scenario has major depression with insomnia, decreased appetite, and weight loss. The preferred drug for this patient is mirtazapine as it is an antidepressant with sedative and appetite-stimulating properties.
  • Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant (a noradrenergic-specific serotonin antagonist).

questions.text: A patient who has been operated for billroth type II surgery develops seizures. Patient had taken lunch 3 hours before this episode, when you do the serum blood glucose of the patient value comes out to be 40 mg/dl. What is the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
Option B. Late dumping syndrome occurs 2 to 3 hours after a meal. It results from excessive movement of sugar into the intestine, which raises the body's blood glucose level and causes the pancreas to increase its release of the hormone insulin. The increased release of insulin causes a rapid drop in blood glucose levels, a condition known as alimentary hypoglycemia, or low blood sugar.

Option A. Early dumping syndrome occurs 10 to 30 minutes after a meal. It results from rapid movement of fluid into the intestine following a sudden addition of a large amount of food from the stomach.The small intestine expands rapidly due to the presence of hypertonic or hyperosmolar contents from the stomach, especially sweet foods. This causes symptoms due to the shift of fluid into the intestinal lumen, with plasma volume contraction and acute intestinal distention.Osmotic diarrhea, distension of the small bowel leading to crampy abdominal pain, and reduced blood volume can result.

Option C. Duodenal stump blowout usually presents as sudden intense thoracoabdominal pain, sudden elevation in pulse and temperature or generalized deterioration of condition.

Option D. Anastomotic leak will come with signs of peritonitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of SIRS?
questions.solution: Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) is an inflammatory state affecting the whole body. It is the body's response to an infectious or noninfectious insult. Although the definition of SIRS refers to it as an "inflammatory" response, it actually has pro- and anti-inflammatory components.

It is a bevelled tube with openings on both the ends, and there are no markings

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria to diagnose true hallucination?
questions.solution:
Criteria to Diagnose Hallucination:

  2. As vivid as real
  3. Experienced in outer objective space.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male has brainstem injury. On examination doctor found respiratory rate is 9 per minute. On spirometry it is found that his inspiratory volume is about 650 ml/ breath. Which respiratory center is likely to be inhibited in this case?
questions.solution:
• Option A - The pneumotaxic center, located in the pons, plays a crucial role in regulating the rate and pattern of breathing.
  • It inhibits the apneustic center and helps to limit the duration of inspiration, thereby promoting normal breathing patterns and a normal respiratory rate.
  • Damage to the pneumatoxic center can result in excitation of apneustic center cause deep and slow respiration.
  • Option b - The apneustic center, also located in the pons, is involved in promoting deep, prolonged inspirations by stimulating the dorsal respiratory group. Its inhibition increases the rate but decreases the depth of respiration.
  • Option c - Dorsal respiratory group mainly causes normal respiration. In it normal inspiration is an active process while normal expiration is passive process.
  • Option d - Ventral respiratory group- It functions in both inspiration and expiration. Totally inactive during normal quite breathing. It operates during overdrive

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Ed page no. 531-532

questions.text: A neonate is suspected to be having congenital heart disease and a chest x ray is done for the same. The chest x-ray shows increased pulmonary markings. Which of the following condition is more likely
questions.solution:
Congenital heart diseases can be classified as:

Decreased pulmonary markings (diminished pulmonary blood flow)

  • Pulmonary atresia or severe stenosis (option a)
  • Tetralogy of Fallot (option c)
  • Tricuspid atresia (option d)
  • Ebstein's anomaly

Increased pulmonary markings (increased pulmonary blood flow)

  • Transposition of great arteries
  • Total anomalous pulmonary venous return
  • Truncus arteriosus

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg: 2413

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant has poor weight gain, a persistent cough, and a history of several bouts of pneumonitis. The mother describes the child as having very large, foul-smelling stools for months. Which of the following diagnostic maneuvers is likely to result in the correct diagnosis of this child?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis is cystic fibrosis (CF)
  • Cystic fibrosis (CF)is a multisystem disease caused by an abnormally functioning cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) protein.
  • Abnormal secretions are produced as a result of decreased permeability of ionized chloride in the secretory epithelium of a number of organs. Progressive lung failure is caused by accumulation of viscid secretions that obstruct the airway and lead to infection, bronchiectasis, and inflammatory changes.
  • CF has common presentations in form of frequent LRTI and symptoms of protein and fat malabsorption due to pancreatic insufficiency.
  • Sweat chloride test is a good screening test in suspected cases of CF.
  • CT chest is not done as a primary screening. (option a)
  • Serum immunoglobulin levels has no role. (option b)
  • Pulmonary TB can be one of the differentials, but foul smelling stools and younger age are points against it. Hence, tuberculin test is not done primarily. (option c)

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st edition, pg: 2282.

questions.text: A 24 year old man presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of palpitations for the past 3 hours. Vital signs showing blood pressure of 100/60 mm Hg, pulse 190 bpm and respirations 14/min. An electrocardiogram showed a picture compatible with Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). Which of the following drug given by intravenous route is most appropriate for the same?
questions.solution:
• Wolff −Parkinson−White (WPW) is a preexcitation syndrome in which there is an accessory bypass tract (known as a Kent bundle) connecting the atrium to the ventricle.
  • An impulse can travel down this pathway and excite the ventricle before the expected regular impulse through the atrioventricular (AV) node; hence the term preexcitation.
  • WPW syndrome can occur in children and adults without overt cardiac disease.
  • A direct current cardioversion represents the treatment of choice for WPW syndrome (for long-term ablation of the accessory pathway).
  • Of the drugs approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, procainamide, which prolongs the refractory period of the accessory pathways, in addition to blocking sodium channels and depressing phase 0, is considered by many the drug of choice.

Features of Class I Anti-arrhythmic Drugs

  • They are Na+ Channel blockers
  • Decreases Slope of Phase 0 depolarization

ECG:

  • Procainamide increases P-R and Q-T intervals and tends to broaden QRS complex.
  • Mechanism of action: Procainamide blocks myocardial Na+ channels in the open state_reduces automaticity and rate of 0 phase depolarization in a frequency dependent manner.
  • Prolongation of APD is due to K+ channel block, while lengthening of ERP is caused by its moderate effect on recovery of Na+ and K+ channels.

Use

  • Procainamide (i.v.) is a second line drug to terminate monomorphic VT and some supraventricular arrhythmias.
  • Many WPW reciprocal VTs respond and it has been used to prevent recurrences of VF.

Option A, B & C: Digoxin, calcium channel blockers, and β-blockers may be dangerous because they can block the AV node and may redirect impulses down the bypass tract.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no: 574

questions.text: A 66 year old female with history of having Congestive heart failure with mild hearing loss is given diuretic agent as part of a standard regimen that includes digoxin and an ACE inhibitor. During the course of treatment, she develops an AV conduction defect and is found to be hypomagnesemic. She also has worsening hearing loss, which is reversed when the drug is stopped. Which of the following drug is involved in such clinical condition?
questions.solution:
• Furosemide can cause hypokalemia by blocking Na+reabsorption in the loop of Henle, followed by exchange of K+ with Na+ in the distal tubules.
  • Hypokalemia is associated with digitalis toxicity. Furosemide also can cause dose-related hearing loss, especially in people with existing hearing loss and/or renal impairment.

Furosemide leads to

  • Hypokalemia,
  • Hypomagnesemia, and
  • Metabolic alkalosis(elevated bicarbonate level).

Hypokalemia

  • This is the most significant Problem
  • Degree of hypokalemia appears to be related to the duration of action of the diuretic; longer acting drugs cause more K+ loss.
  • The usual manifestations are weakness, fatigue, muscle cramps; cardiac arrhythmias are the serious complications.

Magnesium depletion

  • It may develop after prolonged use of loop diuretics, and may increase the risk of ventricular arrhythmias, especially after MI or when patients are digitalized.

Hearing loss

  • This occurs only with high ceiling diuretics, but is infrequent. The risk increases when these drugs are used in the presence of renal insufficiency.
  • Increased salt content of the endolymph and a direct toxic action on the hair cells in internal ear appear to be causative

Alkalosis may occur with hypokalemia, because more H+ exchanges with Na+ in DT when less K+ is available for exchange.


Option A: Acetazolamide is a sulfonamide derivative and can result in bone marrow suppression and hypersensitivity reactions. Other adverse effects include metabolic acidosis (urinary alkalosis) and hypokalemia.

Option B: Amiloride decreases Ca2+ and Mg2+ excretion but increases urate excretion

Option D: Adverse effects of thiazides are similar to loop diuretics except the effect on Ca++ excretion.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no: 631

questions.text: Earliest presenting symptom of Sheehan's syndrome:
questions.solution:
OPTION A: Failed lactation after delivery: The earliest symptom of Sheehan's syndrome, which occurs due to postpartum pituitary necrosis, is often failed lactation or agalactorrhea. The condition results from ischemic damage to the anterior pituitary gland, leading to a deficiency in prolactin production, which is crucial for milk production.

OPTION B: Postural hypotension: While postural hypotension can occur in Sheehan's syndrome due to adrenal insufficiency (from lack of ACTH), it is not typically the earliest symptom. It usually presents later when there is a significant decline in cortisol levels.

OPTION C: Secondary amenorrhoea: Secondary amenorrhoea can be a symptom of Sheehan's syndrome due to reduced secretion of gonadotropins (LH and FSH). However, it usually occurs later than the failed lactation.

OPTION D: Loss of pubic hair: It is a result of a deficiency in adrenal androgens (DHEA), which can happen in Sheehan's syndrome due to hypopituitarism. However, it is not the earliest symptom and occurs later as the condition progresses.

Type: Must know

Topic: Sheehan's syndrome

Reference: Speroff's Clinical Gynaecologic Endocrinology & Infertility 10th edition, Page no: 904.

questions.text:
Adult cells reprogrammed to behave like embryonic stem cells.
This is the characteristic feature of which stem cells?
questions.solution:
Types of Stem Cells:

  1. Embryonic and totipotent Stem Cells are found in the blastocyst stage embryos;
  2. Adult Stem Cells: Found in specific tissues called niches like oval cells in liver, stem cells in crypts of intestine and bulge areas of skin. they typically generate cell types in one lineage.
  3. Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells (iPSCs): Adult cells reprogrammed to behave like embryonic stem cells, with the help of various factors like SOX2/c-myc/Nanog/Oct3-4.

KEY TAKEAWAYS

Adult Cells which are reprogrammed into pluripotent embryonic stem cells are called inducible pluripotent stem cells.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 29.

questions.text: What is the characteristic pattern observed in given portion B (RED ARROW) of electrophoresis image?
questions.solution:
Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death that occurs in a controlled and regulated manner to remove damaged, unnecessary, or harmful cells without causing inflammation.

Key Features:

  1. Cell Shrinkage: Cells shrink and condense.
  2. DNA Fragmentation: The cell's DNA is broken down.
  3. Formation of Apoptotic Bodies: The cell breaks into small, membrane-bound fragments.
  4. Phagocytosis: Apoptotic bodies are engulfed and removed by neighbouring cells or immune cells.

Shown picture is of DNA FRAGMENTATION on agar gel electrophoresis.

Portion A: Normal cells

Portion B: Step ladder pattern

Portion C: Smear pattern

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Apoptosis is characterized by a ladder-like pattern of DNA fragmentation due to cleavage by caspases and endonucleases.

Smear-like pattern can occur in both necrosis and apoptosis, but is less specific.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 37.

questions.text: A patient with a bile duct obstruction develops necrosis of bile duct cells. Which intracellular protein is likely to be elevated in their serum?
questions.solution:
Mechanism:

  1. Bile Duct Obstruction: When the bile ducts are blocked (e.g., by gallstones, tumors, or strictures), bile cannot flow out of the liver properly.
  2. ALP Production: ALP is an enzyme primarily produced by the cells lining the bile ducts. In response to obstruction, these cells increase ALP production.
  3. Leakage into Blood: As bile accumulates, ALP is released into the bloodstream, leading to elevated serum levels.
  1. Necrosis of bile duct cells leads to leakage of ALPinto the bloodstream.
  2. Troponin is elevated incardiacconditions.
  3. LDH is a non-specific enzyme that can be elevated in various conditions.
  4. AST is more specific to liver or cardiac damage.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Necrosis of bile duct cells leads to leakage of ALP into the bloodstream

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO: 39.

The velocity of shortening of the cardiac muscle
The conduction velocity in the atrioventricular (AV) node
The atrial maximum diastolic resting potential

questions.text: A 59 year old male with a history of rheumatic heart disease brought to emergency department with atrial fibrillation (AF). His consulting physician has prescribed him digoxin. Treatment with digoxin converts his AF to a normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following mechanism is most likely responsible for clinical effect?
questions.solution:
• Digoxin is used in atrial fibrillation (AF) to slow the ventricular rate, not usually the AF itself.
  • Digoxin acts to slow the speed of conduction, increase the atrial and AV nodal maximal diastolic resting membrane potential, and increase the effective refractory period in the AV node, which prevents transmission of all impulses from the atria to the ventricles.

Uses

The two main indications of digoxin are

  1. Heart failure
  2. Control of ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation/ flutter.

Mechanism of Action in Atrial Fibrillation

  • In atrial fibrillation (AF), the mechanism of action of digitalis is to cause increased refractoriness of AV nodal pathway (due to vagomimetic action).
  • In AF, atrium beats at very high rate (500 beats/minute), and at such high rates the contractions become ineffective.
  • This is not of very much disadvantage in case of atrium, because it has to give blood only to the ventricles. But if all the contractions are passed to ventricles, cardiac output will decrease, because ventricular contractions will also become ineffective due to this high rate.
  • Thus, aim of treatment in atrial fibrillation is to maintain ventricular rate at low levels.
  • Digitalis does so by its vagomimetic effect that decreases AV conduction.
  • Vagomimetic effect is also responsible for bradycardia due to digitalis therapy.
  • In atrial flutter, it is difficult to control the ventricular rate. Digitalis converts atrial flutter to AF, in which ventricular rate can be controlled easily

Tag: Digoxin

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 561

questions.text: A 60 year old male with a temperature of 104°F and a productive cough came to medicine outpatient department and diagnosed as having staphylococcal pneumonia. After several days of usage of nafcillin, he develops truncal urticaria and pruritus as side effects. Which of the following agent is best avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Cephalosporins and penicillins have similar structures (they have a β-lactam ring), penicillins having a penicillic acid and the cephalosporins a cephalosporinic acid moiety.
  • Both groups of antimicrobials inhibit the transpeptidase enzyme necessary for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer necessary for cell-wall stabilization.
  • The hypersensitivity reactions associated with the penicillins and the cephalosporins appear to be identical in signs and symptoms.
  • There is a crossover sensitivity between the penicillins and cephalosporins that must be considered when a patient is sensitive to either of these antibiotics.

Adverse effects of Penicillins

  • Penicillin G is one of the most nontoxic antibiotics; up to 20 MU has been injected in a day without any organ toxicity.
  • Local irritancy and direct toxicity
    • Pain at i.m. Injection site,
    • Nausea on oral ingestion and
    • Thrombophlebitis of injected vein are dose-related expressions of irritancy.
  • Accidental i.v. injection of procaine penicillin produces CNS stimulation, hallucinations and convulsions due to procaine.

Hypersensitivity

  • Individuals with an allergic diathesis are more prone to develop penicillin reactions.
  • Frequent manifestations of penicillin allergy are
    • Rash,
    • Itching,
    • Urticaria
  • Wheezing, angioneurotic edema, serum sickness and exfoliative dermatitis are less common.

Anaphylaxis is rare (1 to 4 per 10, 000 patients), but may be fatal

  • All forms of natural and semisynthetic penicillins can cause allergy, but it is more commonly seen after parenteral than oral administration.
  • The course of penicillin hypersensitivity is unpredictable, i.e. an individual who tolerated penicillin earlier may show allergy on subsequent administration and vice versa.
  • There is partial cross sensitivity between different types of penicillins; an individual who has exhibited immediate type of hypersensitivity- urticaria, angioedema, bronchospasm, anaphylaxis or serum sickness with one penicillin should not be given any other type of penicillin.
  • If a patient is allergic to penicillin, it is best to use an alternative antibiotic

Tag:cCefazolin

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 769-770

choices.text: Bacterial Conjunctivitis; topical antibiotics and warm compresses
Viral Conjunctivitis; supportive care and antiviral medication
Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis; discontinuation of contact lenses and antihistamine eye drops
Allergic Conjunctivitis; avoidance of allergens and topical mast cell stabilizers

questions.text: A 25-year-old contact lens wearer presents with complaints of itching, redness, and mucous discharge from both eyes. On examination, large papillae are observed on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis is an allergic condition characterized by the formation of large papillae on the inner surface of the upper eyelid, often associated with contact lens use or other foreign bodies.

Causes:

  • Contact Lens Wear: Most common cause; associated with inadequate lens hygiene or prolonged wear.
  • Prothesis or Foreign Bodies: Persistent irritation from ocular prosthetics or foreign objects.
  • Allergic Reactions: Sensitivity to materials or environmental allergens.

Symptoms:

  • Itchy, red, and swollen eyes.
  • Discharge, often mucous or stringy.
  • Sensation of a foreign body in the eye.
  • Visual disturbances due to lens discomfort or irregular corneal surface.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Examination: Visual inspection reveals large, cobblestone-like papillae on the tarsal conjunctiva.
  • Patient History: Assessment of contact lens use and hygiene practices.

Management:

  • Discontinue Contact Lens Use: For a period, switch to glasses or a different type of lens if necessary.
  • Eye Drops: Use of antihistamines or mast cell stabilizers.
  • Improve Hygiene: Proper cleaning of lenses and avoiding irritants.
  • Corticosteroids: Topical steroids for severe cases, under medical supervision.

The image below shows papillae:

Option C) Giant Papillary Conjunctivitis is associated with contact lens wear and presents with large papillae on the tarsal conjunctiva. The symptoms and clinical findings are consistent with this diagnosis.

Option A & B) Bacterial Conjunctivitis and Viral Conjunctivitis typically present with different symptoms and are not associated with large papillae.

Option D) Allergic Conjunctivitis also involves papillary formation but is not specifically linked to contact lens use.

#giant papillary conjunctivitis #FMGE DEC 2021

Reference:

  • Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th Edition, Section on Allergic Conjunctivitis, Page 230-234
  • Ref- parson's 22/e section IV chapter 14 diseases of conjunctiva pg.181

questions.text: Keratoacanthomas is
questions.solution:
• Keratoacanthoma Is self healing nodular lesion with central ulceration

Etiopathogenesis

questions.text:
40-year-old male presents with hematuria and proteinuria. Urine microscopy reveals:


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Figure 1 shows dysmorphic RBCs.
  • Figure 2 shows Red cell cast.

Dysmorphic red blood cells and red blood cell casts are indicative of glomerular damage, which is consistent with glomerulonephritis.

  • Glomerulonephritis is a group of diseases characterized by inflammation of the glomeruli, leading to hematuria, proteinuria, and kidney dysfunction.

Incorrect Options-

A: IgA nephropathy (also called Berger's disease) is a kidney disorder caused by the buildup of IgA antibodies in the glomeruli (filtering units) of the kidneys, leading to inflammation and damage. Caused due to Abnormal deposits of IgA antibodies in the kidneys.

B: Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting the kidneys, eyes, and ears, primarily caused by mutations in genes that produce type IV collagen, an essential part of the kidney's glomerular basement membrane.

C: Thin Basement Membrane Disease (TBMD), also known as benign familial hematuria, is a genetic condition characterized by a thinning of the glomerular basement membrane in the kidneys.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Glomerulonephritis is a group of diseases characterized by inflammation of the glomeruli, leading to hematuria, proteinuria, and kidney dysfunction.

Reference: ESSENTIALS OF CLINICAL PATHOLOGY, 2ND EDITION, PAGE NO. 38.

questions.text: A 70 years old male visited orthopaedic with complaint of limp during walking. He had recently operated for right hip bone surgery. On examination, doctor found Trendelenburg's sign was positive. Which of the following nerve is likely to damaged ?
questions.solution:
Superior gluteal nerve: Injury to nerve lead to paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus muscle. Patient bends or lurches on paralysed side to clear opposite side. This is known as lurching gait.

  • When the body weight is supported on one limb, the glutei of the supported side raise the opposite and unsupported side of the pelvis.
  • However, if the abductor mechanism is defective, the unsupported side of the pelvis drops and this is known as a positive Trendelenburg's sign.
  • The sign is positive in defects of power i.e. paralysis of glutei medius and minimus; defect of fulcrum, i.e. congenital or pathological dislocation of the hip and defect of the weight, i.e. ununited fracture of the neck of the femur.

In the below image; there is right sided superior gluteal nerve palsy

  • When the left foot is taken off the ground: left side pelvis sags, which is compensated by lurching on the right side.

Option wise explanation:

Option B: Inferior gluteal nerve : Injury to nerve lead to gluteal maximus paralysis. It will cause inability to stand from sitting posture without support.

Option C: Sciatic nerve : Injury to nerve lead to paralysis of hamstring muscle and all muscles of leg. The patient has foot drop.

Option D: Femoral nerve : Injury to nerve lead to paralysis of muscles of front of thigh that will lead to inability to extend the knee joint.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 2. 9th edition. Page No 82.

questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrect for joint and its type ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A: Subtalar joint: It is joint between concave facet on inferior surface of body of talus and convex facet on middle one third of superior surface of calcaneum. It is plane synovial joint.

Option B: Talocalcaneonavicular joint: The head of talus fits into socket formed partly by navicular bone and partly by calcaneum. It is ball and socket joint.

Option C: Calacaneocuboid: It is joint between concavo-convex articular surfaces of calcaneum and cuboid. It is a saddle joint.

Option D: Metatarsophalangeal joint: It is between metatarsal and phalangeal bones. It is a ellipsoid type of the synovial joint.

Reference: Human Anatomy. B D Chaurasia. Volume 2. 9th edition. Page No 183.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with symptoms of hypoglycemia. Laboratory results show:
Fasting plasma glucose: 50 mg/dL
Which of the following laboratory findings indicates endogenous insulin production?
questions.solution:
C-peptide is a byproduct of endogenous insulin production, making it a useful indicator of residual beta-cell function.

C-peptide has several functions:

  1. Insulin production indicator: Measuring C-peptide levels can help determine if the body is producing enough insulin.
  2. Diabetes diagnosis and monitoring: C-peptide levels can help diagnose and monitor diabetes, as they can indicate the body's ability to produce insulin.
  3. Insulinoma diagnosis: High C-peptide levels can indicate the presence of an insulinoma, a rare tumor of the pancreas that produces excess insulin.
  4. Research applications: C-peptide is used in research studies to investigate insulin production, glucose metabolism, and diabetes.

Incorrect Options-

C, D. Glucagon level is not directly related to endogenous insulin production.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- A Insulin level can be influenced by exogenous insulin administration

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1100.

questions.text: Budding is seen with which fungus?
questions.solution:
CRYPTOCOCCUS-

  • 5-10 μm with narrow budding, PAS positive.
  • Found in soil, pigeon droppings.
  • Acquired through inhalation with hematogenous dissemination to meninges.
  • Highlighted with India ink and mucicarmine (red inner capsule).
  • Latex agglutination test detects polysaccharide capsular antigen and is more sensitive and specific.
  • Causes cryptococcosis, which can manifest with meningitis, pneumonia, and/or encephalitis ("soap bubble" lesions in brain), primarily in immunocompromised.
  • Treatment: amphotericin B + flucytosine followed by fluconazole for cryptococcal meningitis.

Soap bubble appearance in CNS Cryptococcosis

CANDIDA

  • Dimorphic; forms pseudohyphae and budding yeasts at 20°C, germ tubes at 37°C.
  • Systemic or superficial fungal infection. Causes oral and esophageal thrush in immunocompromised (neonates, steroids, diabetes, AIDS), vulvovaginitis (diabetes, use of antibiotics), diaper rash, infective endocarditis (people who inject drugs), disseminated candidiasis (especially in neutropenic patients as host defense relies on phagocytes), chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.
  • Treatment: oral fluconazole/topical azoles for vaginal; nystatin, azoles, or, rarely, echinocandins for oral; fluconazole, echinocandins, or amphotericin B for esophageal or systemic disease.

A) Cryptococcus & Candida- Correct. Both Cryptococcus and Candida are fungi that reproduce by budding. Cryptococcus, a yeast, reproduces through budding (blastoconidia), while Candida, which is yeast-like, reproduces via budding and binary fission.

B) Candida & Rhizopus- Incorrect. While Candida reproduces by budding, Rhizopus is a Mold that reproduces primarily through the formation of sporangia and not budding.

C) Rhizopus & Mucor - Incorrect. Rhizopus and Mucor are both molds that reproduce by forming sporangia and are not characterized by budding.

D) Candida & Aspergillus - Incorrect. Candida reproduces by budding, but Aspergillus, a mold, reproduces through the formation of conidia and not budding.

Key Takeaway: Budding is a reproductive feature seen in Cryptococcus and Candida. Rhizopus, Mucor, and Aspergillus utilize different reproductive mechanisms.

Tag Line: Moderate

Reference: Textbook of Medical Mycology Hardcover - 1 January 2018, by Jagdish Chander (Author). Chapter 20.

questions.text: A diabetic patient suffers from a soft tissue infection, and microbiological examination reveals the infection to be caused by fungi with aseptate and broad hyphae. Which of the following fungi is responsible for this infection?
questions.solution:
Irregular, broad, non septate hyphae branching at wide angles.



Causes mucormycosis, mostly in patients with DKA and/or neutropenia (e.g., leukemia). Inhalation of spores of fungi proliferate in blood vessel walls, penetrate cribriform plate, and enter brain.

Rhinocerebral, frontal lobe abscess; cavernous sinus thrombosis. Headache, facial pain, black necrotic eschar on face; may have cranial nerve involvement. Treatment: surgical debridement, amphotericin B, or isavuconazole.

A) Candida - Incorrect. Candida typically presents as yeast forms and may form pseudohyphae, but it does not exhibit broad, aseptate hyphae.

B) Aspergillus - Incorrect. Aspergillus is a septate fungus with narrow, septate hyphae, not broad and aseptate.

C) Penicillium - Incorrect. Penicillium is also a septate fungus with narrow hyphae, which is not broad or aseptate.

D) Apophysomyces - Correct. Apophysomyces is a genus of Mucorales fungi characterized by aseptate and broad hyphae, and it is associated with soft tissue infections in immunocompromised individuals, such as diabetic patients.

Key Takeaway: Apophysomyces, a fungus with aseptate and broad hyphae, is commonly responsible for soft tissue infections in diabetic or immunocompromised patients.

Tag Line: Moderate

Reference: Textbook of Medical Mycology Hardcover - 1 January 2018, by Jagdish Chander (Author). Chapter 26, Page 554.

HDV cannot infect in the absence of HBV

questions.text: For HDV false is:
questions.solution:
HDV is a RNA Delta virus, transmitted by parenteral, sexual, and perinatal route.

It is a Defective virus -Depends on HBV HBsAg coat for entry into hepatocytes.



A) Both can infect simultaneously - HBV and HDV can indeed infect simultaneously (coinfection) or sequentially (superinfection).

B) HDV causes more serious infection due to superinfection-. Superinfection with HDV in an HBV carrier can cause more severe liver disease.

C) HDV cannot infect in the absence of HBV - Incorrect. HDV requires HBV for infection, as it uses HBV surface antigens for its envelope.D) HDV is a DNA virus - Correct. Hepatitis D virus (HDV) is an RNA virus, not a DNA virus.

Key Takeaway: HDV is an RNA virus, not a DNA virus.

Tag Line: Moderate

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Hepatitis D. CDC Hepatitis D

questions.text: HIV primarily infects which of the following cells in the immune system?
questions.solution:
• HIV attacks and destroys the CD4 cells (CD4 T lymphocyte) of the immune system. CD4 cells play a major role in protecting the body from infection.
  • HIV uses the machinery of the CD4 cells to multiply and spread throughout the body. This process, which is carried out in seven steps or stages, is called the HIV life cycle.



A) Red blood cells - Incorrect. HIV does not primarily infect red blood cells; it targets immune cells.

B) B lymphocytes - Incorrect. While HIV can affect B cells indirectly, it primarily infects CD4+ T cells.

C) CD4+ T cells - Correct. HIV primarily infects CD4+ T cells, which are crucial for the immune response.

D) Neutrophils - Incorrect. Neutrophils are not the primary targets of HIV infection.

Key Takeaway: HIV specifically targets and destroys CD4+ T cells, leading to immune system compromise. The HIV life cycle is critical to understanding how the virus replicates and spreads within the body, and it forms the foundation for developing antiretroviral therapies (ART). Each stage of the life cycle is a target for specific drugs designed to inhibit viral replication and prevent the progression of HIV infection to AIDS.

Tag Line: Easy

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). HIV Basics. CDC HIV Basics

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a pathological effect of free radicals?
questions.solution:
Free radical injury occurs when highly reactive molecules (free radicals) cause cellular damage. Here are the key pathological effects:

  1. Lipid Peroxidation: Damage to cell membranes, leading to increased permeability and cell dysfunction.
  2. Protein Damage: Oxidation of proteins, causing misfolding and loss of function.
  3. DNA Damage: Mutations in DNA, contributing to cancer and genetic disorders.
  4. Mitochondrial Dysfunction: Impaired energy production and increased ROS generation.
  5. Inflammation: Triggers chronic inflammation and worsens conditions like atherosclerosis.
  6. Cell Death: Leads to necrosis or apoptosis, involved in diseases like heart attacks and strokes.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Free radicals can cause oxidative damage to DNA, lipids, and proteins, leading to various pathological conditions, including cancer, aging, and neurodegenerative disorders. However, free radicals do not increase cellular respiration.

REFERENCE: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 53.

choices.text: To regulate telomere length and maintenance
To maintain protein homeostasis and remove damaged cellular components
To induce apoptosis and cell death

questions.text: What is the primary function of autophagy in cellular aging?
questions.solution:
Autophagy slows cellular aging by:

  1. Removing damaged components like proteins and organelles.
  2. Responding to stress, aiding cell survival.
  3. Clearing damaged mitochondria, reducing oxidative stress.
  4. Preventing cellular senescence, keeping cells functional.
  5. Maintaining protein quality, and reducing age-related diseases.

Explanation:

  1. Autophagy maintains protein homeostasis by removing damaged or dysfunctional cellular components, such as proteins and organelles.
  2. Cellular senescence regulated by telomere attrition and activation of tumor suppressor genes.
  3. Telomere length and maintenance are regulated by telomerase and other proteins.
  4. Apoptosis and cell death are regulated by other mechanisms.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Autophagy protects cells from aging and supports longevity.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 68.

questions.text: What is the primary vector responsible for transmitting yellow fever virus to humans?
questions.solution:
A) Anopheles mosquito - Incorrect. The Anopheles mosquito is primarily responsible for transmitting malaria, not dengue. Sits at an angle to surface.

B) Aedes mosquito - Correct. The Aedes mosquito, specifically Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, is the primary vector responsible for transmitting the dengue virus to humans.

C) Culex mosquito - Incorrect. Culex mosquitoes are vectors for other diseases such as West Nile virus and filariasis, but not dengue.

D) Tsetse fly - Incorrect. The tsetse fly is the vector for trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), not dengue fever.

Key Takeaway: The Aedes mosquito is the primary vector for dengue fever transmission. Understanding these properties helps in devising control measures and public health interventions to mitigate the spread of diseases transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.

Tag Line: Hard

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Dengue Transmission. CDC Dengue Transmission

questions.text: What should be the appropriate management of a young patient with cervical cancer <3mm with no lymph-vascular space invasion?
questions.solution:
The 2018 FIGO staging of cervical CA is as follows:

Stagewise Management :

OPTION A: Radical trachelectomy is a fertility-sparing surgery that removes the cervix, upper part of the vagina, and surrounding tissues while preserving the uterus. It is suitable for early-stage cervical cancer (usually stage IA2 to IB1) in patients who wish to maintain fertility and have tumors smaller than 2 cm.

OPTION B: Cone biopsy involves removing a cone-shaped section of the cervix and is generally used for very early-stage cancers or precancerous lesions. It is less suitable for a 2 cm tumor as it may not provide adequate margins for cancer control in this scenario.

OPTION C: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy + Cone biopsy is not typically recommended as standard treatment for cervical cancer of this size, especially when fertility preservation is considered.

OPTION D: Ovarian transposition and radiotherapy is used when radiotherapy is planned to preserve ovarian function by moving the ovaries out of the radiation field. However, radiotherapy itself would compromise fertility due to uterine exposure, making it less desirable for a nulliparous woman wishing to retain fertility.

Type: May know

Topic: Management of Cervical Cancer

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Page no. 667-668

questions.text: The incision preferred during autopsy in case of asphyxial death due to neck compression is
questions.solution:
• The incision preferred in the case of asphyxial death due to neck compression (as in hanging, strangulation etc.) is the Y-shaped incision.
  1. I-shaped incision: The usual incision is drawn from just below the chin to the pubic symphysis avoiding the umbilicus and any injuries in the line of incision. This is the most common method followed.
  2. Y-shaped incision: The two incisions commence on either side of the neck from 2 to 3 cm behind the lobe of each ear to meet at manubrium sterni and then continued as a single incision down to pubic symphysis avoiding the umbilicus. It is used when a detailed study of neck organs is required, such as death due to compression on the neck (hanging or strangulation) and any condition where the larynx might be damaged, as the skin of the upper neck can then be dissected off the mandible and raised clear to give a wide approach to the neck structures.
  3. Modified Y-shaped incision: Two incisions are made, commencing on either side of the chest starting from both acromia, running away and below the breasts to meet at xiphisternum and to be continued as a single vertical incision down to pubic symphysis avoiding the umbilicus. This is desirable in those cases (especially females) where it is customary to restore the body in a reasonable cosmetic condition for view for some time after death.
  4. Inverted Y- shaped incision: An incision from the symphysis menti to umbilicus, then extending to bilateral mid-inguinal point. It is used in foetus and new-born to study umbilical arteries.

Reference: Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 5th Edition, Kishan Vij, Page no. 20; Knight's Forensic Pathology, 4th Edition, Page N0. 19

questions.text: A child has high grade fever and laryngeal stridor. X ray chest shows steeple sign. Which of the following is not an indication to admit the child?

questions.text: A newborn is examined immediately after an induced vaginal delivery for fetal growth retardation. On visual inspection, the infant has low-set ears, a small mandible, and a prominent occiput. The neonate has a weak cry and increased tone of the extremities, including clenched hands with second and fifth digits on top of the third and fourth digits. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh, IV/VI holosystolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border. Which of the following explains these features?
questions.solution:
• This patient has trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome), in which a complete extra copy of chromosome 18 is inherited as a result of meiotic nondisjunction.
  • Features of DiGeorge syndrome (22q11 deletion) include aortic arch anomalies, thymic hypoplasia/aplasia, and hypocalcemia (parathyroid gland underdevelopment). Phenotypically, neonates can present with hypertelorism, low-set ears, micrognathia, and cleft palate. (Option a)
  • Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) presents with midline facial defects (eg, holoprosencephaly, cleft lip/palate), musculoskeletal abnormalities (eg, polydactyly), and gastrointestinal anomalies (eg, omphalocele, umbilical hernia). Trisomy 13 is notably not associated with overlapping fingers. (Option b)
  • Cri-du-chat syndrome (5p deletion) presents with a weak or "cat-like" cry as well as hypotonia, failure to thrive, and developmental delay. Phenotypic features include microcephaly, low-set ears, hypertelorism, and a broad nasal bridge. (Option d)

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 659

questions.text: A child suspected to have Celiac disease is to be evaluated. Which of the following will be 1st line screening investigations you will advise in the child, based upon the latest guidelines?
questions.solution:
This is the recommended first-line screening approach. IgA Tissue Transglutaminase (TTG) is the most sensitive and specific test for Celiac disease, and measuring Total Serum IgA is important to rule out IgA deficiency, which can lead to false-negative results.

If the IgA TTG test is positive, further confirmatory testing like a biopsy or additional antibody testing may be done.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant presents to your clinic because the mother is concerned that he is not eating well and he has been constipated. The mother tells you that her prenatal course and delivery were uneventful. On physical examination, the infant has a puffy face, large tongue, and persistent nasal drainage. Which of the following conditions is most likely to present with these findings?
questions.solution:
• Most infants with congenital hypothyroidism are asymptomatic at birth. Feeding difficulties, choking spells, and somnolence often present during the first month of life. Respiratory distress can also occur in part due to the large tongue and nasal obstruction.
  • On physical examination, you may find a large abdomen, umbilical hernias, subnormal temperature, cold skin, murmurs, or bradycardia.
  • Profound dietary deficiency of iodine will result in hypothyroidism and is the most common cause of goiter in the world.
  • Rickets results from a deficiency of vitamin D. This condition predominately affects the long bones and skull. (option b)
  • Pallor is the most important sign of iron-deficiency anemia. Children may also have the desire to ingest unusual substances such as ice or dirt. (option c)
  • Finally, hyponatremia and hypoglycemia are the prominent presenting signs of adrenal insufficiency in infants. (option d)

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 2914

questions.text: A 6-month-old male presents with poor weight gain. His diet consists only of goat milk. On examination, he appears tired and with mild tachycardia. Which of the following laboratory value most likely to be elevated?

  • As child is on goat milk, he will be having deficiency of folic acid and B12.
  • Vitamin B9 (Folate) Deficiency is associated with high red blood cell mean corpuscular volume and low folate level leading to megaloblastic anemia and hyper segmented neutrophils.
