questions.text: While at school, a 6-year-old boy is noted by his teacher to experience 10- to 20-second lapses in consciousness, sometimes with clonic movements of the face. His parents have not noticed this behavior at home. Electroencephalography shows 3 per second generalized spike and wave discharges. The MOST appropriate therapy for this boy is:
questions.solution:
• Absence seizures are one of several kinds of seizures. These seizures are sometimes referred to as petit mal seizures (from the French for "little illness", a term dating from the late 18th century). Absence seizures are characterized by a brief loss and return of consciousness, generally not followed by a period of lethargy (i.e., without a notable postictal state).
  • Treatment of patients with absence seizures only is mainly with valproic acid or ethosuximide, which are of equal efficacy controlling absences in around 75% of patients.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 3095

questions.text: The image below shows a microscopic view of a blood smear or a tissue sample showing filarial parasites. Based on the appearance and specific characteristics in the image, which parasite is depicted?
questions.solution:
It is identified by the presence of sheathed microfilariae with an undulating motion and no nuclei at the tip.

A) Correct: Wuchereria bancrofti is characterized by its sheathed microfilariae with an undulating motion, typically observed in blood samples. The sheathed structure and specific movement patterns are key identifiers.

B) Incorrect: Brugia malayi also causes lymphatic filariasis and has sheathed microfilariae, but differs in some morphologic details compared to Wuchereria bancrofti.-It has 2 nuclei at it's tip.

C) Incorrect: Onchocerca volvulus microfilariae are unsheathed and typically do not show the sheathed structure seen in Wuchereria bancrofti.

D) Incorrect: Loa loa microfilariae are larger and unsheathed, exhibiting a cork-screw motion, which is different from the sheathed microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti.


Tag Line: Hard

Key Takeaway:
Wuchereria bancrofti is identified by its sheathed microfilariae and undulating motion in blood samples, which is crucial for distinguishing it from other filarial species.

Reference:
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Filariasis. CDC Filariasis

questions.text: Examine the image below showing a blood smear. What is the most likely parasite shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Plasmodium vivax is one of the five species of malaria parasites that infect humans. It is responsible for vivax malaria, which is generally less severe than Plasmodium falciparum malaria but can still lead to significant morbidity due to its relapsing nature.

  • Life Cycle:
    • After a mosquito bite, sporozoites enter the bloodstream and infect liver cells, where they develop into hypnozoites (dormant forms) or continue as merozoites that invade red blood cells.
    • Hypnozoites can remain dormant in the liver for months or years and reactivate to cause relapses of malaria.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Causes tertian malaria, where fevers recur every 48 hours.
    • Symptoms include fever, chills, sweating, headache, nausea, and fatigue.
    • Can lead to severe anemia due to the parasite's invasion of red blood cells.
    • Relapses are common due to reactivation of hypnozoites from the liver.
  • Gametocytes:
    • Unlike P. falciparum, Plasmodium vivax gametocytes are round in shape, not banana-shaped.

A) Babesia microti: This parasite causes babesiosis and can be identified by the presence of ring forms, but often lacks the specific multi-ring forms or schizonts seen in the image.

B) Trypanosoma brucei: Causes African sleeping sickness and is usually found in blood as trypomastigotes, not ring forms inside red blood cells.

C) Plasmodium vivax: The image shows schizonts, which are characteristic of Plasmodium vivax, a common cause of malaria.

D) Leishmania braziliensis: Typically found in tissue samples or bone marrow smears, not in blood smears.

Key Takeaway: Plasmodium vivax is identified by ring forms and schizonts within red blood cells, which are specific to malaria diagnosis.

Reference: For further details on Plasmodium vivax and its blood smear identification, see the CDC's malaria resources: CDC - Malaria.

questions.text:
A patient with respiratory symptoms and a history of bird exposure presents for evaluation. The biopsy image shows small, round yeast cells inside macrophages.

Which fungal infection does this biopsy most likely represent?
questions.solution:
Also known as OHIO / darling / cave disease.

Dimorphism:

  • In the environment (25°C), Histoplasma exists in a mold form with tuberculate macroconidia.
  • In human tissues (37°C), it takes on a yeast form, which causes infection.

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Acute Pulmonary Histoplasmosis: Symptoms resemble flu or pneumonia, with fever, cough, and chest pain.
  • Chronic Pulmonary Histoplasmosis: Resembles tuberculosis, often seen in individuals with underlying lung conditions.
  • Disseminated Histoplasmosis: A severe form that spreads beyond the lungs to other organs, particularly in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV/AIDS patients).

A) Histoplasmosis: Small yeast cells within macrophages are characteristic of Histoplasma capsulatum.

B) Coccidioidomycosis: Shows spherules with endospores and barrel shaped arthrospores.


C) Cryptococcosis: Features large yeast cells with a thick capsule on Indian Ink preparation.


D) Candidiasis: Shows yeast cells with pseudohyphae, not intracellular.

Key Takeaway: Histoplasmosis is identified by small yeast cells within macrophages, especially in patients with a relevant exposure history.

Reference: CDC Histoplasmosis Overview

questions.text: Examine the provided electron microscope image. What virus is shown?
questions.solution:
• It is a is filamentous with a helical structure, appearing as long, thread-like particles.
  • Option A) Ebola Virus: Ebola Virus is filamentous with a helical structure, appearing as long, thread-like particles.
  • Option B) Dengue Virus: Dengue Virus particles are spherical with a smooth surface, not filamentous.
  • Option C) SARS-CoV-2: SARS-CoV-2 has a spherical shape with spike proteins but does not have the filamentous structure depicted.
  • Option D) Rotavirus: Rotavirus is characterized by a wheel-like (or double-layered) structure and is not filamentous.

Key Takeaway: Ebola Virus is distinct due to its filamentous, thread-like appearance, which is essential for its identification.

Reference: For more information on the Ebola Virus, refer to the CDC: CDC - Ebola Virus.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old female presents with Cushing's syndrome and a 3 cm mass in the lung. Biopsy reveals:

1. Small, round cells with scant cytoplasm with no necrosis
2. Positive immunostaining for chromogranin A, and synaptophysin
3. Ki-67 index of 1%

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The biopsy findings of small, round cells with positive immunostaining for chromogranin A, and synaptophysin support a neuroendocrine tumor.
  • There is no necrosis which points towards bronchial carcinoid.
  • The low Ki-67 index (1%) indicates a well-differentiated tumor, consistent with OPTION A NET G1 (bronchial carcinoid tumor).

Incorrect Options-

B: Small cell lung carcinoma: also a neuroendocrine tumor

  • Typically presents with aggressive symptoms, such as weight loss, cough, and chest pain
  • There will be Azzopardi effect
  • Biopsy shows small, round cells with scant cytoplasm, but:

Usually has a high Ki-67 index (>50%)

No necrosis,

Typically doesn't produce ACTH, so wouldn't cause Cushing's syndrome

Often has a different immunostaining profile (e.g., positive for CD56, TTF-1)

C: Adenocarcinoma of the lung: glandular histologly

  • Most common type of lung cancer, often presents with cough, chest pain, or incidental finding.
  • Biopsy shows glandular or acinar architecture, but:

Typically doesn't produce ACTH, so wouldn't cause Cushing's syndrome

Often has a different immunostaining profile (e.g., positive for TTF-1, CK7)

Can have a variable Ki-67 index

D: squamous cell carcinoma lung has keratin pearls in histopathological examination.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- small, round cells with positive immunostaining for ACTH, chromogranin A, and synaptophysin support a neuroendocrine tumor. The low Ki-67 index (1%) indicates a well-differentiated tumor, consistent with NET G1 (bronchial carcinoid tumor).

Reference: robbins & cotran, 10th edition, page no. 1116.

questions.text: Based on the volume time plot shown in blue, what is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
In Obstructive Diseases:

  • The slope of the volume-time curve during expiration is less steep or flattened. This occurs because the flow of air during exhalation is slower due to narrowed or obstructed airways.
  • The forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) is reduced, meaning the person cannot exhale as much air in the first second of forced expiration.
  • The forced vital capacity (FVC) may also be reduced, though not as much as FEV1, leading to a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio (which is a key diagnostic criterion for obstructive lung disease).

Among the given options in question, Bronchiectasis is an obstructive lung disease.

questions.text: A patient on ampicillin therapy for upper respiratory tract infection developed pseudomembranous colitis. Preferred treatment is ?
questions.solution:
• Clostridium difficile colonizes the human intestinal tract typically after the normal gut flora has been altered by antibiotic therapy and causes antibiotic-associated colitis.
  • The antibiotics most frequently implicated in predisposition to Clostridium. difficile infection (CDI) are fluoroquinolones, clindamycin, cephalosporins, and penicillins
  • Fidaxomicin and vancomycin can be used in the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis

questions.text: A patient on treatment for MDR TB presents with weight gain and cold intolerance and lethargy. Lab evaluation showed elevated TSH, low T3 and low T4. Which drug is responsible ?
questions.solution:
Ethionamide can lead to hypothyroidism through the following mechanisms:

  1. Inhibition of Thyroid Hormone Synthesis:
    • Ethionamide can interfere with the synthesis of thyroid hormones by inhibiting the enzyme thyroid peroxidase (TPO), which plays a critical role in the synthesis of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4). By inhibiting TPO, ethionamide disrupts the iodination of tyrosine residues in thyroglobulin, a crucial step in thyroid hormone production.
  2. Disruption of Iodine Metabolism:
    • Ethionamide may also impair the uptake of iodine by the thyroid gland, which is essential for thyroid hormone production. This effect can further decrease the gland's ability to synthesize adequate amounts of thyroid hormones.
  3. Thyroid Gland Inflammation:
    • Ethionamide can cause mild inflammation or even direct damage to the thyroid gland, leading to its dysfunction and contributing to a decrease in thyroid hormone levels.

questions.text: What is the primary function of Neutrophil Extracellular Traps (NETs)?
questions.solution:
Neutrophil Extracellular Traps (NETs) are web-like structures composed of DNA, histones, and antimicrobial proteins released by neutrophils during a process called NETosis. They are part of the immune system's defense mechanism against infections.

Key Points:

  1. Function: NETs trap and neutralize pathogens like bacteria, fungi, and viruses, preventing their spread.
  2. Components: Made of neutrophil DNA, histones, and granular proteins (e.g., elastase, myeloperoxidase) that have antimicrobial properties.
  3. Formation: NETosis occurs when neutrophils release their DNA in response to infections or inflammatory stimuli.
  4. Role in Disease: While beneficial in controlling infections, excessive NET formation can contribute to inflammation and tissue damage in conditions like autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus) and thrombosis.

They play a crucial role in antimicrobial defense, particularly against bacteria, fungi, and parasites.

Incorrect Options-

A. Phagocytosis is a process by which neutrophils internalize pathogens, but it's not the primary function of NETs.

C. Inflammation resolution is not directly related to NETs.

D. Cytokine production is a function of various immune cells, including neutrophils, but not the primary function of NETs.

Key takeaways- NETs play a dual role in immunity, defending against pathogens but also potentially causing harm in inflammatory diseases.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran, 10th edition, page no. 83-84.

questions.text: A 28 year old male patient came to medicine department with complains of fever. He was being treated for leukemia. His physician has given him agents that will cover bacterial, viral and fungal infections. Two days later, he develops acute renal failure. Which of the following drug was most likely responsible for development of acute renal failure?
questions.solution:
Amphotericin B may alter kidney function by decreasing creatinine clearance; if this occurs, the dose must be reduced.

  • It also commonly increases potassium (K+) clearance, leading to hypokalemia, and causes anemia and neurologic symptoms.
  • A liposomal preparation may reduce the incidence of renal and neurologic toxicity.
  • However, because of higher toxicity of AMB, the azole antifungals are now preferred in conditions where their efficacy approaches that of AMB.
  • In serious fungal infections, especially in immunocompromised patients, initial induction therapy with AMB may be replaced by the alternative safer azole antifungal drug for continuation of therapy.

Option A: Vancomycin is less likely to cause kidney damage; if it does, the damage is less severe.

Option B: Cephalosporins have low-grade nephrotoxicity which may be accentuated by pre-existing renal disease, concurrent administration of an aminoglycoside or loop diuretic.

Option D: Dose-dependent decrease in g.f.r. is the most important toxicity; occurs especially in those with kidney disease; normalises on discontinuation of the drug.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 840

questions.text: A 56 year old male patient with chronic history of having an autoimmune disorder was on prednisone therapy for long time. He was brought to his orthopaedic physician seeking treatment for drug induced osteoporosis. Which of the following mechanism is accurately associated with development of osteoporosis by chronic use of glucocorticoids?
questions.solution:
Glucocorticoid - induced osteoporosis is attributed to inhibition of calcium absorption as well as bone formation.

  • Glucocorticoid - induced Osteoporosis: especially involves vertebrae and other flat spongy bones.
  • Compression fractures of vertebrae and spontaneous fracture of long bones can occur, especially in the elderly.
  • Corticosteroid induced osteoporosis can be prevented/arrested to some extent by calcium supplements + vit D, but bisphosphonates are the most effective drugs in this regard.
  • Avascular necrosis of head of femur, humerous, or knee joint is an occasional abrupt onset complication of high dose corticosteroid therapy.

Option A: Glucocorticoid leads to inhibition of calcium absorption

Option C: Glucocorticoid suppresses rather than stimulate the hypothalamic -pituitary - adrenal axis.

Option D: The decreased production of prostaglandins does not play a role in bone formation.

[Glucocorticoids]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 317-318

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with hypogonadism is treated with a synthetic androgen. Which of the following is activated by a synthetic androgen?
questions.solution:
• A variety of drugs that resemble steroid hormones in their structure can traverse cellular membranes and bind to specific cytoplasmic receptors that bind heat shock proteins. Among these are the synthetic androgens.
  • These agents bind reversibly to the cytoplasmic receptor, causing release of the heat shock proteins, followed by an irreversible activation step.
  • Next, the steroid-receptor complex enters the nucleus of the cell and regulates transcription of specific genes into RNA.
  • Eventually, mRNA is formed and causes the synthesis of specific proteins that mediate the steroid response.

Schematics of Glucocorticoids actions

↓

The glucocorticoid (G) penetrates the cell membrane

↓

Binds to the glucocorticoid receptor (GR) protein that normally resides in the cytoplasm in association with heat shock protein 90 (HSP90)

↓

Binding of the steroid to GR dissociates the complexed proteins (HSP90, etc) removing their inhibitory influence on it.

↓

A dimerization region that overlaps the steroid binding domain is exposed, promoting dimerization of the occupied receptor.

↓

The steroid bound receptor dimer translocates to the nucleus

↓

Binds coactivator/corepressor proteins and interacts with specific DNA sequences called 'glucocorticoid responsive elements' (GREs)

↓

The expression of these genes is consequently altered resulting in promotion (or suppression) of their transcription.

↓

The specific mRNA thus produced is directed to the ribosome where the message is translated into a specific pattern of protein synthesis, which in turn modifies cell function.

[Androgen]

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no: 61

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the following image ?
questions.solution:
Sebaceous cyst is a non-fluctuant, compressible mass and has a central, dark comedone opening (punctum) . Cysts are usually asymptomatic, can be found anywhere but are commonly found on the face, neck, chest, upper back, scrotum, and genitals. If cyst ruptures it may closely resemble a furuncle with tenderness to palpation, erythema, and swelling. A foul-smelling yellowish cheese-like material discharged from the skin may be described.

Option A. A dermoid cyst is a teratoma of a cystic nature that contains an array of developmentally mature, solid tissues. It frequently consists of skin, hair follicles, and sweat glands, while other commonly found components include clumps of long hair, pockets of sebum, blood, fat, bone, nails, teeth, eyes, cartilage, and thyroid tissue.

As dermoid cysts grow slowly and contain mature tissue, this type of cystic teratoma is nearly always benign. In those rare cases wherein the dermoid cyst is malignant, a squamous cell carcinoma usually develops in adults, while infants and children usually present with an endodermal sinus tumor.

questions.text: What is the use of the catheter shown in the following figure ?
questions.solution: Fogarty Catheter : Fogarty arterial embolectomy catheter is a device developed in 1961 by Dr. Thomas J. Fogarty to remove fresh emboli in the arterial system. It consists of a hollow tube with an inflatable balloon attached to its tip. The catheter is inserted into the blood vessel through a clot. The balloon is then inflated to extract it from the vessel. It is available in different lengths and sizes, and is often colour coded by size. Because it is less invasive than ordinary surgery, it reduces the chance of postoperative complications.

questions.text: A 40 years old male visited hospital with sudden onset of left sided facial drop. On examination there is inability to raise left eyebrow, incomplete eye closure on left side and drooping of mouth. He denies any recent trauma or fever. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Bell's palsy : It is as infra-nuclear lesion of Facial nerve (LMN PALSY) in which the whole of face is paralyzed on same side. Face becomes asymmetrical and is drawn to the normal side.

Characteristic features :

  • Facial symmetry : due to unopposed action of muscle of normal side.
  • Loss of wrinkles on forehead : due to paralysis of occipitofrontalis muscle
  • Inability to close the eye : due to paralysis of orbicularis oculi
  • Sagging of angle of mouth : paralysis of zygomatic major
  • Accumulation of food into vestibule of mouth : due to paralysis of Buccinator
  • Dribbling of saliva from angle of mouth : due to paralysis of orbicularis oris

Supranuclear facial palsy - UMN palsy

Infranuclear facial palsy - LMN palsy

Option wise explanation :

Option A. Left supranuclear facial palsy : will have paralysis of lower quarter of right side.

Option B. Left Infranuclear facial palsy : will have paralysis of upper and lower quarter of left side.

Option C. Right supranuclear facial palsy : will have paralysis of lower quarter of left side.

Option B. Right Infranuclear facial palsy : will have paralysis of upper and lower quarter of right side

questions.text: 09 Year old Child presented with Glossitis, Cheilosis and Corneal Vascularization. Which Biochemical Enzyme assay is useful for identification of nutrient Deficiency in this child?

Riboflavin provides the reactive moieties of the coenzyme Flavin Mononucleotide (FMN) and Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD).

In the red Blood Cells, HMP pathway is sole source of NADPH for Reduction of Oxidized Glutathione by Glutathione Reductase - Flavoprotein containing FAD. So In the deficiency of Riboflavin - FAD is not produce which will affects the activity of RBC Glutathione Reductase enzyme.

Option A: In Pentose Phosphate Pathway, Non-Oxidative phase generates precursor for Ribose, Ribose 5 Phosphate which is required for Nucleic Acid and Nucleotide Synthesis. In this reactions Transketolase helps in conversion of a ketose sugar into an aldose sugar with two carbon less and an aldose sugar into ketose with two carbon more. The reaction requires Mg+ and TPP (Thiamine) as coenzyme. Measurement of erythrocyte Transketolase provides an index of Nutritional Status of Thiamine (B1).

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with sudden onset of diplopia and drooping of the right eyelid. On examination, the right eye shows limited upward movement, while the left eye moves normally. Which cranial nerve is most likely affected in this case?
questions.solution:
Ophthalmoplegia refers to the paralysis or weakness of the muscles that control eye movement, leading to difficulty in moving the eyes. This condition can affect one or both eyes and can be due to various underlying causes.

Key Aspects of Ophthalmoplegia

  • Types:
    • Monocular Ophthalmoplegia: Involves paralysis of the muscles controlling one eye.
    • Binocular Ophthalmoplegia: Involves paralysis of the muscles controlling both eyes.
  • Causes:
    • Neurological Disorders: Such as stroke, multiple sclerosis, or Guillain-Barré syndrome.
    • Infections: Such as herpes zoster ophthalmicus.
    • Trauma: Injury to the cranial nerves.
    • Tumors: Such as a pituitary adenoma affecting the cranial nerves.
    • Myasthenia Gravis: An autoimmune disorder causing weakness of the eye muscles.
  • Signs and Symptoms:
    • Ptosis: Drooping of the upper eyelid.
    • Diplopia: Double vision.
    • Limited Eye Movements: Difficulty moving the eye in one or more directions.
    • Misalignment of Eyes: Eyes may appear to be crossed or deviated.
  • Treatment:
    • Treating the Underlying Cause: Such as managing diabetes, treating infections, or addressing neurological conditions.
    • Prisms: To help manage diplopia.
    • Eye Exercises: To strengthen the eye muscles and improve movement.
    • Surgical Intervention: In cases where ptosis or severe misalignment is present.

Option B) Cranial Nerve III (Oculomotor Nerve) is responsible for most eye movements, lid elevation, and pupillary constriction. Paralysis of this nerve can cause ptosis, diplopia, and limited eye movements.

Option A) Cranial Nerve II (Optic Nerve) is responsible for vision and does not control eye movements.

Option C) Cranial Nerve IV (Trochlear Nerve) and

Option D) Cranial Nerve VI (Abducent Nerve) control specific eye movements but not lid elevation.

Reference:

  • Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th Edition, Chapter on Eye Movement Disorders, Page 250-255

questions.text: Parents with a family H/O diabetes decided to promote their children to stay away from mobile and computers and spend more time in outdoor activities. Level of prevention:
questions.solution:
• Primordial prevention refers to actions taken to prevent the development of risk factors themselves before they emerge. In this case, encouraging children to engage in outdoor activities and avoid sedentary behaviors (such as excessive use of mobile phones and computers) aims to prevent the development of risk factors for diabetes (like obesity or physical inactivity).
  • Primary specific prevention involves preventing a specific disease or condition by controlling its risk factors, but this scenario is broader, focusing on lifestyle changes rather than a specific preventive measure like vaccination or medication.
  • Health promotion refers to broader actions that improve overall health and well-being, but the focus here is on preventing the development of risk factors for diabetes, fitting the definition of primordial prevention.
  • Secondary prevention refers to early detection and treatment of an existing condition, which is not applicable here as the goal is to avoid the development of risk factors in the first place.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Primordial prevention refers to the prevention of the development of risk factors themselves, aiming to prevent the emergence of environmental, social, or economic conditions that contribute to disease.

It focuses on modifying lifestyle and societal factors from an early stage, such as promoting healthy habits, reducing pollution, and creating supportive environments to avoid the onset of risk factors like hypertension, obesity, or unhealthy behaviors.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-02, Page no.:34-38.

questions.text: A 30 year old man working in the battery industry for the last 10 years, reported to emergency unit with c/o severe abdominal pain. On examination, positive findings were blue line on gum, basophilic stippling of RBC, serum lead concentration 80 micro gram/ dl. Most probable cause of exposure:
questions.solution:
• The patient works in the battery industry, which is a well-known source of inorganic lead exposure.
  • Symptoms like severe abdominal pain, blue line on the gums (Burton's line), and basophilic stippling of RBCs are classic signs of lead poisoning.
  • The serum lead concentration of 80 micrograms/dL is significantly elevated, confirming lead exposure.

Incorrect Options :

  • Asbestos is associated with respiratory diseases like asbestosis or mesothelioma but does not present with these symptoms.
  • Sugar cane bagasse exposure can cause respiratory issues (like bagassosis), but it is unrelated to lead poisoning.

Thus, the most probable cause of exposure is lead.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Symptoms like severe abdominal pain, blue line on the gums (Burton's line), and basophilic stippling of RBCs are classic signs of lead poisoning.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-18, Page no.:936-940.

questions.text: Country is showing slow increase in population due to low birth and death rate but still birth rate is more than death rate. Demographic cycle is:
questions.solution:
• Late expanding phase is characterized by a situation where the population growth rate is positive but slowing down due to a decline in both birth and death rates. In this phase, birth rates are still higher than death rates, leading to a slow population increase.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The demographic cycle (or demographic transition) refers to the sequence of stages a country passes through from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates as it develops economically and socially.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-08, Page no.:566-570.

questions.text: Acculturation may take place by
questions.solution:
Acculturation refers to the process through which individuals or groups from one culture come into contact with and adopt elements of another culture. This can happen through various means, including:

  • Education: Exposure to different cultural ideas and practices through schools or formal learning.
  • Industrialization: The spread of industrial practices and technologies that may influence cultural values and lifestyles.
  • Trade and commerce: Interaction between different cultural groups through the exchange of goods and services can lead to the exchange of cultural practices and ideas.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed to have synovial chondromatosis in his right knee joint. Which of the following is false in view of synovial chondromatosis ?
questions.solution:
seen in 30 to 50 yr old population

Synovial Chondromatosis

  • Definition:
    • Chronic proliferative disorder affecting joints or bursae.
    • Ranges from metaplasia of the synovial tissue to firm nodules of cartilage.
    • The nodules get calcified and results in formation of multiple intraarticular loose bodies.
  • Presentation:
    • Patients under 30 years old. (Option D)
    • Symptoms include pain, stiffness, and swelling. (Option C)
    • Most commonly affects the knee.
  • Imaging:
    • Shows intraarticular fine, stippled calcification known as "loose bodies."
    • MRI is the IOC. (Option A)
  • Treatment:
    • Arthroscopic resection of loose bodies. (Option B)
    • Synovectomy to remove affected synovial tissue.

Note:

Loose Bodies in the Joint

  • Common Problem:
    • Frequently occurs in the knee joint.
  • Common Cause:
    • Fractured osteophyte becoming loose in an osteoarthritic joint.
  • Other Causes:
    • Knee osteochondritis.
    • Osteochondral fractures.
    • Synovial chondromatosis (more than 50-60 bodies).
  • Symptoms:
    • Sudden locking of the joint.
    • Patient may feel the loose body within the joint.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Most loose bodies are radiopaque and visible on plain X-rays.
    • Arthroscopic examination may be needed in some cases.
  • Treatment:
    • Removal of the loose body either arthroscopically or through open joint surgery.

Reference: Miler's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 1867

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 326.

questions.text: The main tissue responsible for degeneration of joint in rheumatoid arthritis is ........?
questions.solution:
Synovium gets converted to pannus around the cartilage in rheumatoid arthritis. Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the synovium leads to pannus formation which produces enzymes that destroy bone and cartilage.

Rheumatoid Arthritis

  • Definition:
    • Chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints.
  • Pathology:
    • Initial Changes:
      • Synovium becomes oedematous.
      • Filled with fibrin exudates and cellular infiltrates.
      • Increase in synovial fluid.
    • Progressive Changes:
      • Synovium hypertrophies and forms a pannus around the cartilage. (Option A,B,C and D)
      • Articular cartilage loses its smooth, shiny appearance.
      • Pannus extends over and burrows into the subchondral bone.
      • Cartilage wears off, leading to raw bone surfaces.
      • Joint deformity results from muscle spasm, pain, and fibrosis of the capsule and soft tissue structures.
    • Advanced Disease:
      • Adhesions between layers of pannus may cause fibrous ankylosis, and later bony ankylosis.
      • Joint capsule distends due to hypertrophied synovium and synovial fluid.
      • Ligaments stretch, leading to joint subluxation.
      • Osteoporosis develops in bones adjacent to the joint.
      • Peri-articular tissues (tendons, muscles) may become oedematous, infiltrated with cells, and may rupture.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 287.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for the following fundus photo with egg-yolk appearance at the fovea?
questions.solution:
Vitelliform dystrophy (also known as Best disease) is characterized by a yellow, egg-yolk-like lesion at the fovea, which can resemble an egg yolk due to the accumulation of lipofuscin material in the retinal layers.

  • Best disease is an inherited retinal dystrophy that results from a mutation in the BEST1 gene and is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion.
  • A dysfunction of the protein bestrophin results in abnormal fluid and ion transport by the RPE.
  • Lipofuscin (periodic acid-Schiff [PAS] positive) accumulates within the RPE cells
  • ERG is normal but EOG is abnormal(<150).

D) Retinitis pigmentosa: This condition typically presents with night blindness, tunnel vision, and retinal bone spicule pigmentation rather than the egg-yolk appearance.

questions.text:
In the emergency department the nurse is running toward the resuscitation room with a limp, cyanotic, pulseless, apneic, 11-month-old child in his arms. The child was previously healthy. One provider begins giving bag-mask ventilations with 100% FiO2 while another establishes intraosseous access, and a third begins administering high-quality chest compressions. The following rhythm is seen on the monitor.
Of the following, the BEST next step in the management of this patient is
questions.solution:
• The patient described in this vignette has pulseless ventricular tachycardia. Therefore, the best next step, after starting high-quality cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is defibrillation.
  • Ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia should be treated with early defibrillation before other interventions (e.g., epinephrine administration, endotracheal intubation), and pulse check should not delay defibrillation. (option a, b)
  • The dose for the initial defibrillation attempt is 2 J/kg.
  • Rhythms that should be treated with synchronized cardioversion include unstable supraventricular tachycardia, atrial tachycardia, and ventricular tachycardia with a pulse. (option d)

(Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 2443)

questions.text: Which of the following is the only bisphosphonate currently approved for intravenous use in paget's disease?
questions.solution:
BISPHOSPHONATES

  • The bisphosphonates are analogues of pyrophosphate, with high affinity for bone, especially in areas of increased bone turn over, where they are powerful inhibitors of bone resorption.
  • The bisphosphonates are concentrated in areas of high bone turn over and are taken up by and inhibit osteoclast action.
  • The potency of the compounds for inhibition of bone resorption varies a thousand fold, increasing in the order of etidronate, tiludronate, pamidronate, alendronate, and risedronate.
  • Pamidronate is the only bisphosphonates currently approved for intravenous use in paget disease.

Paget's disease

  • This disease due to abnormal osteoclast function producing disordered bone remodeling and honeycomb-like bone architecture is benefited by BPNs.
  • Bisphosphonates arrest osteolytic lesions, reduce bone pain and improve secondary symptoms. Long-lasting remissions may be induced.

Pamidronate

  • A second generation potent BPN which is administered only by i.v. infusion in weekly or monthly depending on the condition.

Uses

  • Paget's disease
  • Hypercalcemia of malignancy
  • Bony metastasis.

Adverse effects

  • Thrombophlebitis of injected vein
  • Bone pain
  • Fever and Leukopenia.

A flu-like reaction may occur initially due to cytokine release

Tag: Pamidronate

Tag Line: Good to Know

questions.text: Following is endocrine disorder. Identify it.
questions.solution:
Cushing is state of excess cortisol

Etiology: ↑ cortisol due to a variety of causes:

  • Exogenous glucocorticoids ↓↓ ACTH leads to bilateral adrenal atrophy (most common cause of Cushing)
  • Primary adrenal adenoma, hyperplasia, or carcinoma ↓↓ ACTH leads to atrophy of uninvolved adrenal gland.
  • ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease);
  • paraneoplastic ACTH secretion (eg small cell lung cancer, bronchial carcinoids) leads to bilateral adrenal hyperplasia.

Clinical features: MOON FACIES:

  • Metabolic syndrome (hypertension, hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia)
  • Obesity (truncal weight gain with wasting of extremities, round "moon" facies (A), dorsocervical fat pad "buffalo hump")
  • Osteoporosis,
  • Neuropsychiatric (depression, anxiety, irritability),
  • Facial plethora,
  • Androgen excess (acne, hirsutism),
  • Cataract,
  • Immunosuppression,
  • Ecchymoses (easy bruising),
  • Skin changes (thinning, striae(b), hyperpigmentation)

questions.text: The primary function of counter current exchanger mechanism is
questions.solution:
Countercurrent mechanism works as follows

It is made up of loop of Henle and vasa recta

Consists of two components:

  • Counter current multiplier
  • Formed by loop of henle
  1. Passive transport of sodium ions from ascending thin segment into the interstitium
  2. Active transport of sodium from inner medullary collecting duct
  3. Diffusion of urea from the collecting duct into medullary interstitium
  4. Responsible for establishing hyperosmolality and gradient in medulla
  • Counter current exchanger

Formed by vasa recta

Responsible for maintenance of the medullary gradient and hyperosmolality

  • Option a and b - Na+ and water reabsorption occurs actively in the loop of henle but primary function is forming medullary osmolarity.
  • Option d - Acid base balance has no relation to counter current mechanism.

questions.text: A 34 year old lady presents to labour ward at 36 weeks gestation with chest pain. An ECG is performed. Which of the following ECG changes in not a normal variation in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
OPTION A. 15-20 degrees left axis shift

A left axis deviation of about 15-20 degrees is considered a normal variation in pregnancy. This shift occurs due to the elevated diaphragm and the enlarged uterus pushing the heart slightly to the left and upward.

OPTION B: Transient ST Segment depression
Explanation: Mild and transient ST segment depression can occur during pregnancy due to increased cardiac output and normal physiological changes. It is generally not indicative of pathological conditions but should be evaluated in the context of symptoms.

OPTION C. T wave inversion in inferior and lateral leads

T wave inversions in inferior (II, III, aVF) and sometimes lateral leads (V5, V6) can be a normal finding in pregnancy due to the hormonal and hemodynamic changes affecting the heart's electrical conduction. However, these should be mild and not associated with other signs of ischemia.

OPTION D. ST Elevation

ST elevation is not typically seen as a normal ECG change in pregnancy. ST elevation usually suggests myocardial injury or pericarditis, which are pathological conditions requiring urgent attention. It is not a normal finding in a healthy pregnant woman

Type: Good to know

Topic: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Page no. 2391

questions.text: A 26 year old lady is going to work abroad for three months. She is currently 12 weeks pregnant and is enquiring about vaccination. Which of these vaccinations is contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
OPTION D: MMR vaccine is contraindicated during pregnancy because it contains live attenuated viruses, which could potentially harm the developing fetus. It is recommended to receive the MMR vaccine before pregnancy or postpartum.

OPTION A. Inactivated influenza vaccine is safe and recommended during pregnancy, especially during flu season, to protect both the mother and the baby from influenza-related complications.

OPTION B. Pertussis (whooping cough) vaccine is recommended during pregnancy, typically given between 27 and 36 weeks gestation, to protect the newborn from whooping cough, which can be severe in young infants.

OPTION C. Diphtheria toxoid is also safe and recommended during pregnancy. It is often given as part of the Tdap vaccine (tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis) to protect both the mother and baby.

All live vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy except yellow fever

Type: Must know

Topic: Immunization in pregnancy

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Page no. 442

questions.text: Which pelvic diameter is most critical in determining the adequacy of the pelvis for vaginal delivery?
questions.solution:
It is the shortest diameter, thus the crucial diameter.

OPTION D: Interspinous diameter: This diameter measures the distance between the ischial spines, and it is crucial in assessing the adequacy of the pelvic outlet for vaginal delivery. A narrow interspinous diameter can indicate a reduced pelvic outlet size, which could affect the feasibility of a vaginal delivery.

OPTION A: Transverse diameter of the outlet: This diameter is important for assessing the width of the pelvic outlet but is not the most critical for determining the adequacy for delivery.

OPTION B: True conjugate: This is the measurement from the sacral promontory to the upper margin of the symphysis pubis. It is crucial for evaluating anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic inlet rather than the outlet.

OPTION C: Obstetric conjugate: This is the distance from the sacral promontory to the closest point on the posterior pubic symphysis. It is a measure anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic inlet and not directly related to the outlet.

Type: Must know

Topic: Diameters of pelvis

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Page no. 88

questions.text:
In a patient of Temporal bone fracture with facial nerve injury. The assessment has been done to find the site of injury of facial nerve canal.
Schirmer's test shows decreased lacrimation, taste sensation is impaired and stapedial reflex is absent. Where is the level of injury?
questions.solution:
The facial nerve travels through several segments in the temporal bone, like labyrinthine segment, horizontal(tympanic) segment and vertical(mastoid) segment.

Decreased lacrimation (Schirmer's test): This indicates parasympathetic dysfunction, which is carried by the greater petrosal nerve, a branch of the facial nerve that originates in the labyrinthine segment, at geniculate ganglion.

The chorda tympani, a branch of the facial nerve, provides taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. The chorda tympani exits the facial nerve at the vertical segment

The stapedial reflex is mediated by the stapedius muscle, which is innervated by a branch of the facial nerve that originates in the 2nd genu.

As mentioned in the question, loss of all sensations would result from injury at most proximal location of course of nerve.

However, both a and c would be the answer the most appropriate and most closest answer will be geniculate ganglion.

questions.text: A 75 year-old diabetic patient presents with severe pain in the ear and facial palsy. Examination reveals granulation tissue in external auditory canal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms described — severe ear pain, facial palsy, and the presence of granulation tissue in the external auditory canal — are highly suggestive of malignant otitis externa. This is a severe, often life-threatening infection that typically affects elderly diabetic patients, especially those with poor glucose control.

It is a misnomer, it is not a cancerous condition.

It is often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which can lead to osteomyelitis of the skull base and cranial nerve involvement.

Managed by giving 3rd generation cephalosporins.

Other options:

  • Keratosis obturans: This condition involves the accumulation of keratin in the external auditory canal, leading to a blocked ear.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma ear canal: While this type of cancer can present with ear pain and granulation tissue, it would not usually cause facial palsy early in the disease course, and it is less likely to cause acute pain as seen in this case. Also, the patient's age and history of diabetes point more toward an infectious process.
  • Exostosis of External auditory canal: Exostoses are bony growths in the ear canal, commonly associated with frequent exposure to cold water. They are typically painless and do not cause granulation tissue, facial palsy, or infection.

questions.text: A lady presents with thin frothy discharge with red vagina. On saline microscopy, motility is seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The green frothy discharge, red strawberry cervix and vagina, motile flagellated trichomonas. And the diagnosis is trichomoniasis.

Treatment of trichomonas is metronidazole. Partner treatment is recommended as well

questions.text: Which of the following contraceptive methods provides the most effective protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs)?
questions.solution:
OPTION B: Condoms are the only contraceptive method listed that provides significant protection against STIs, including HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and others. They are protective even for cervical cancers also. They act as a physical barrier, preventing the exchange of bodily fluids during sexual activity.

OPTION A: Oral contraceptive pills are highly effective in preventing pregnancy but do not provide any protection against STIs, as they do not act as a barrier between partners.

OPTION C: Intrauterine devices (IUD) are highly effective in preventing pregnancy, but they do not provide any protection against STIs. In fact, if a person with an IUD contracts an STI, the risk of pelvic inflammatory disease can increase.

OPTION D: Implants are a long-acting reversible contraceptive method that effectively prevents pregnancy but offers no protection against STIs, as they do not prevent the exchange of fluids during sexual intercourse.

Type: Must know

Topic: STI prevention

Reference: Speroff’s Gynaecology 9th edition, Page no. 2495

questions.text: A patient presented with painless chronic ear discharge, pale granulations in the middle ear & facial palsy with the following picture of Tympanic Membrane on otoscopic examination. Most Probable diagnosis
questions.solution: Tubercular otitis media is a rare form of otitis media caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It typically presents with a painless chronic ear discharge, and there is usually a history of systemic tuberculosis. It is associated with multiple perforations on tympanic membrane, like shown in the image.

questions.text: While Otoscopy, patient started coughing. Stimulations of which nerve leads to cough in this case?
questions.solution:
Arnold's nerve, also known as the auricular branch of the vagus nerve, is responsible for the sensory innervation of the posterior wall and floor of external auditory canal, and the tympanic membrane. Stimulation of this nerve can trigger a cough reflex due to its connection with the vagus nerve, which is involved in the cough reflex arc.

Other options:

B. Jacobson's nerve: Jacobson's nerve is a Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, associated with ear ache after tonsillectomy.

D. Vidian Nerve: The Vidian nerve (also called the nerve of the pterygoid canal). it is cut in treatment for vasomotor rhinitis (vidian neurectomy).

C. Nerve of Wrisberg: This is a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve that innervates the eustachian tube and the middle ear.

A young Diabetic patient on with high glycosylated hemoglobin levels has presented to ENT OPD with blood stained nasal discharge, eye swelling, blurring of vision and recent history of loose upper teeth
Which of the following is the first investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
The condition described is Mucor mycosis (early stage). It is best diagnosed by biopsy or MRI with contrast .the better answer would be biopsy if given both as options. the finding seen on imaging is black turbinate. The risk factors for Mucor mycosis are HIV, diabetic patients, covid patients, steroid intake and neutropenic patients.

Nasal swab doesn’t help because it is angioinvasive fungus.

questions.text: Environmental manipulation to which enable genes to express themselves readily is known as
questions.solution:
Euthenics refers to environmental manipulation to improve human well-being by enhancing the conditions in which people live, thereby enabling genes to express themselves more favorably. This contrasts with eugenics, which focuses on genetic selection or modification.

  • Positive Eugenics (a) aims to encourage reproduction among people with desirable traits.
  • Negative Eugenics (b) seeks to reduce reproduction among people with undesirable traits.

questions.text: A 28 year old male presents with complaints of headache since 3-4 days, also having photophobia & Fever with temperature of 102 F. On examination Neck stiffness present with Kerning Sign positive. He is having past medical history of Human Immunodeficiency Virus (Hiv) Infection and Intravenous Drug Use (IDU). He is non-compliant with Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy (HAART) Medication. CD4 Count is 50. A lumbar puncture is taken and an analysis of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows budding yeast cells which stain strongly to Indian ink. Most likely causative agent for above condition will be?
questions.solution:
The most likely causative agent in this case is B. Cryptococcus neoformans.

  • This patient has advanced HIV/AIDS with a very low CD4 count (50 cells/mm³) and presents with symptoms of meningitis (headache, photophobia, fever, neck stiffness, and Kernig's sign). The presence of budding yeast cells in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) that stain with Indian ink is characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans, a common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with AIDS.
  • Cryptococcal meningitis is frequently seen in patients with CD4 counts below 100 cells/mm³ and is confirmed with India ink staining, which highlights the encapsulated yeast.

Incorrect Options:

A: Toxoplasma gondii, typically causes cerebral abscesses

C: Pneumocystis jirovecii causes pneumonia.

D: Cytomegalovirus is more likely to cause retinitis or encephalitis, rather than meningitis with these findings.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Cryptococcal meningitis is a severe fungal infection of the meninges, primarily caused by Cryptococcus neoformans and Cryptococcus gattii.

It is a leading cause of opportunistic central nervous system (CNS) infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with advanced HIV/AIDS

The fungus is acquired through inhalation of desiccated yeast cells or spores, often from environmental sources like bird droppings (especially pigeons). The fungus disseminates from the lungs to the CNS via the bloodstream. Once in the CNS, it causes inflammation of the meninges (meningitis) or mass lesions (cryptococcosis).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K.park,27th Edition, Page no.398-403

questions.text:
Which of the following indicators are used in Waterlow's classification?
1. Weight for age
2. Height for age
3. Weight for height
4. BMI for age
5. Head circumference for age
questions.solution:
Waterlow's classification

  • Makes use of height for age (HFA) and weight for height (WFH) to assess the nutritional status of children.
  • HFA indicates stunting and denotes the chronicity of malnutrition.
  • On the other hand, WFH indicates wasting and denotes the severity of malnutrition.

Weight for Age denotes undernutrition.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Waterlow's classification

  • Makes use of height for age (HFA) and weight for height (WFH) to assess the nutritional status of children.
  • HFA indicates stunting and denotes the chronicity of malnutrition.
  • On the other hand, WFH indicates wasting and denotes the severity of malnutrition.

REFERENCE: Park's Textbook of preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, Chapter 9, Page No-629-634.

questions.text: A patient presented with loose stools and skin rashes over the sun-exposed areas. Diet history revealed that the patient had been consuming a jowar-rich diet since childhood. This condition results due to excess of which amino acid in the diet?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of pellagra. It is caused by the excess of leucine in jowar.

  • Excess of leucine in jowar (sorghum) and maize interferes with the conversion of tryptophan to niacin causing pellagra. It presents with the following features:
    • Diarrhea
    • Dermatitis (sun-exposed areas)
    • Dementia

People consuming jowar also have a higher risk of developing genu valgum and osteoporosis due to greater retention of ingested fluoride.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Pellagra is characterised by -Diarrhea, dermatitis and dementia

REFERENCE:- Park's Textbook of preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, Chapter 11, Page No-734.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is considering starting a hormonal contraceptive but is concerned about its effect on her bone density. Which of the following is the most likely hormonal method to affect bone density?
questions.solution:
OPTION C: Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is a progestin-only injectable contraceptive, is associated with a decrease in bone mineral density, especially with long-term use (more than two years). This effect is reversible after discontinuation, but it is the most likely hormonal method to affect bone density adversely among the listed options. given as 150mg injection every 3 months.

OPTION A: Combined oral contraceptive pills contain both estrogen and progestin, which generally do not have a negative impact on bone density. In some cases, they may even have a protective effect on bone health.

OPTION B: Contraceptive patch delivers both estrogen and progestin through the skin. It does not negatively affect bone density and may help maintain or improve bone health due to the presence of estrogen.

OPTION D: Contraceptive implants which release a small amount of progestin over time, have not been shown to significantly affect bone density in most users, unlike DMPA.

Type: Must know

Topic: DMPA & its adverse effects

Reference: Speroff's Gyanecology 9th edition, Page no. 2417

questions.solution: The reason for isthmus being most common location for tubal sterilization is its nature of linear and narrow part, and if there is a need for re-anastomosis it is easier to do.

questions.text: Most common cardiac lesion seen in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
OPTION B: Mitral stenosis is the most common cardiac lesion in pregnancy, often due to rheumatic heart disease. Pregnancy increases blood volume and cardiac output, which can worsen symptoms of mitral stenosis, such as pulmonary congestion and atrial fibrillation, posing risks to both the mother and fetus.

OPTION A: Mitral regurgitation is relatively common in pregnancy due to increased blood volume and cardiac output, which can exacerbate existing valve insufficiency. However, it is not the most common cardiac lesion; it usually presents as a functional or physiological regurgitation without significant hemodynamic compromise.

OPTION C: Aortic stenosis is less common in pregnancy compared to mitral valve lesions. Severe cases can pose significant risks due to fixed cardiac output that cannot meet the increased demands of pregnancy, but it is not the most prevalent condition.

OPTION D: Pulmonary regurgitation is typically mild and often clinically insignificant in pregnancy. It is generally well tolerated due to the low-pressure nature of the right side of the heart, and it is far less common as a primary cardiac lesion compared to mitral stenosis.

Therefore, mitral stenosis is the most common cardiac lesion seen in pregnancy, particularly in regions where rheumatic heart disease is prevalent.

Type: Must know

Topic: Mitral stenosis

Reference: Arias' practical guide to high risk pregnancy & delivery 4th edition, Page no. 276

choices.text: External cephalic version and trial of vaginal delivery
External cephalic version followed by Caesarean section

questions.text: Ideal management of 37 weeks uncomplicated breech pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
a) External cephalic version and trial of vaginal delivery

  • Explanation: External cephalic version (ECV) is a procedure performed at or after 37 weeks of gestation to turn the fetus from a breech position to a cephalic (head-down) position. The goal of ECV is to enable a vaginal delivery, reducing the need for a Caesarean section. If the ECV is successful and there are no contraindications, a trial of vaginal delivery can be offered. This option is ideal as it aims to promote a vaginal birth, which has fewer risks of complications associated with surgery. However, the success rate of ECV is variable, and it requires careful monitoring.

b) External cephalic version followed by Caesarean section

  • Explanation: This option is less commonly recommended because if the ECV is successful, the primary goal is to proceed with a vaginal delivery. Planning a Caesarean section after a successful ECV is contradictory, as the intent of ECV is to avoid a surgical delivery. Caesarean section would be reserved if the ECV fails or if other complications arise that necessitate surgery.

c) Spontaneous vaginal delivery

  • Explanation: While some breech presentations can be delivered vaginally, it requires careful selection of cases and an experienced team. Most guidelines recommend against spontaneous vaginal breech delivery in uncomplicated cases at term because of the increased risks for both mother and fetus, such as cord prolapse, head entrapment, and traumatic injury.

d) Caesarean section straightaway

  • Explanation: This option is generally preferred in term breech pregnancies to avoid the complications associated with breech vaginal deliveries. While Caesarean section provides a controlled environment to reduce risks, it is not the ideal initial management if ECV is available and there are no contraindications to attempting a vaginal delivery.

Key takeaway: The ideal management for a 37-week uncomplicated breech pregnancy would be to attempt an External Cephalic Version (ECV) followed by a trial of vaginal delivery if successful. This approach provides an opportunity to avoid surgery and promotes natural birth, assuming the ECV is successful and there are no other contraindications for vaginal delivery.

Type: Must know

Topic: Singleton Breech Delivery

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Page no. 1353

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents for a health check-up, during which the doctor finds that he is reluctant to talk about his illnesses. He is suspicious that the information will be used to harm him. He does not trust his family either for the same reason. He does not forgive easily and bears grudges. What is the type of personality disorder that he has?
questions.solution:
Paranoid personality disorder (PPD) is characterized by pervasive distrust and suspicion of others. People with PPD often believe that others are out to harm or deceive them, including family members, and may find it difficult to forgive perceived wrongs.

The patient's reluctance to talk about his illnesses due to suspicion that the information will be used to harm him, along with his lack of trust in his family and tendency to bear grudges, fits this description.

A. Schizoid personality disorder: Individuals with schizoid personality disorder are often detached from social relationships and show limited emotional expression

B. Schizotypal personality disorder: This disorder involves odd beliefs, eccentric behaviors, and social anxiety.

D. Histrionic personality disorder: People with histrionic personality disorder seek attention and may be overly emotional.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the psychiatric outpatient department after a nervous breakdown. He says that he got divorced about a week ago, and has been feeling depressed since then. He has also started hearing voices for the past few days, saying he is useless and telling him to kill himself. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Brief psychotic disorder or acute psychotic disorder is characterized by the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms (such as delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech) that last for at least one day but less than one month.

A. Schizophrenia: Schizophrenia is a chronic mental disorder characterized by persistent symptoms of psychosis (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized thinking) lasting for at least six months.

B. Schizophreniform disorder: This is diagnosed when psychotic symptoms occur for more than one month but less than six months..

D. Major depressive disorder: While major depressive disorder can include depressive symptoms and suicidal ideation, it typically does not include psychotic symptoms such as hallucinations. To diagnose, there should be more than 5 symptoms for more than or equal to 14 days.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
On a CT scan of the brain, the Lentiform Nucleus appears as a lens-shaped structure. It consists of the putamen and globus pallidus, and is located in the deep structures of the brain, adjacent to the internal capsule.

It is positioned between the caudate nucleus (medially) and the internal capsule (laterally).

The caudate nucleus lies medially to the lentiform nucleus and is typically C-shaped and located near the lateral ventricle

The thalamus is more centrally located in the brain, deeper than the lentiform nucleus, and has a more symmetrical, oval shape on CT.

The internal capsule appears as a white matter tract separating the lentiform nucleus from the caudate nucleus and thalamus.

C - Caudate nucleus (atrophied in Huntington's chorea)

T - Thalamus (sensory relay centre)

G - Globus pallidus

P - Putamen (site of hypertensive bleed)

AL & PL - Anterior and Posterior limb of internal capsule.

When the caudate nucleus gets atrophied, there is enlargement of frontal horns of lateral ventricles, giving it a box car ventricle appearance.

questions.solution: Oral abortifacients, such as mifepristone and misoprostol, are used to terminate pregnancies, typically within the first 9 weeks of pregnancy. A pregnancy of 8 weeks duration is within the window where oral abortifacients are typically used

questions.text: Which test use whole blood as sample in detection of TB
questions.solution:
The Interferon Gamma Release Assay (IGRA) is a blood test used to detect latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI). It measures the release of interferon-gamma from T-cells in response to specific TB antigens. The test uses whole blood as the sample.

a. CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test): This test detects the genetic material of Mycobacterium tuberculosis in sputum or other clinical samples,

c. Line probe assay: This test is used for the detection and identification of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and drug resistance, typically using sputum or other biological samples.

d. Liquid culture: This is a method to grow Mycobacterium tuberculosis from sputum or other specimens to diagnose active tuberculosis.

choices.text: Resistance to INH - Amikacin + Ofloxacin + Ethambutol
Resistance to INH + rifampicin + Moxifloxacin + Linezolid

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, productive cough, and weight loss. He gives a history of not having completed treatment for tuberculosis thrice in the past. Extensively drug-resistant TB is suspected. How is this entity defined?
questions.solution:
XDR-TB (extensively drug-resistant TB) is defined as multi-drug-resistant TB (resistant to rifampicin and isoniazid) which is also resistant to one fluoroquinolone (e.g. ofloxacin) AND resistant to at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

It is usually seen in patients who have previously received treatment for TB and have either failed to complete treatment or relapsed.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- XDR-TB (extensively drug-resistant TB) is defined as multi-drug-resistant TB (resistant to rifampicin and isoniazid) which is also resistant to one fluoroquinolone (e.g. ofloxacin) AND resistant to at least one additional group A drug

REFERENCE: Park's Textbook of preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, Chapter 5, Page No-207-240.

questions.text: Concept of 'Social physician' given by which committee?
questions.solution:
The Bhore Committee, officially known as the Health Survey and Development Committee, was set up by the Government of India in 1943 under the chairmanship of Sir Joseph Bhore. It is one of the most significant committees in the history of healthcare planning in India. Below are key details about the Bhore Committee:

  1. Comprehensive Health Services: Recommended the establishment of a comprehensive, government-funded healthcare system available to all citizens, regardless of their ability to pay.
  2. Primary Health Centers (PHCs): Proposed the establishment of PHCs across rural India to provide essential health services, with one PHC serving 40,000 people.
  3. Three-tier System: Advocated a three-tier structure for health services:
    1. Primary Level: PHCs and sub-centers.
    2. Secondary Level: District hospitals.
    3. Tertiary Level: Specialist hospitals in urban areas.
  4. Focus on Preventive Healthcare: Emphasized preventive and promotive healthcare, particularly in maternal and child health, sanitation, and control of communicable diseases.
  5. Integration of Preventive and Curative Services: Proposed the integration of preventive, curative, and rehabilitative services at all levels of care.
  6. Health Manpower Development: Suggested the creation of new medical and nursing colleges to address the shortage of trained healthcare professionals.
  7. Emphasis on Rural Health: Focused on improving rural healthcare infrastructure to reduce the disparity between urban and rural healthcare services.
  8. Free Medical Care: Recommended free healthcare services for all citizens, removing financial barriers to access.
  9. Community Participation: Encouraged community involvement in healthcare planning and implementation at the local level.
  10. Public Health Education: Stressed the importance of health education for disease prevention and health promotion in the population.

KEY TAKEAWAYS - The Bhore Committee's vision continues to influence health policies in India, particularly its emphasis on rural healthcare, primary health services, and preventive medicine. It was a pioneering effort in shaping the healthcare landscape of post-independence India.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-10, Page no. 713-715.

questions.text: Bartholin's gland in females is homologous to which of the following in males:
questions.solution:
The table below mentions all the homologous structures of male and female reproductive system and their origin.



OPTION A: Penile urethra is homologous to labia minora in females.

OPTION B: Cowper's glands, also known as bulbourethral glands in males, are the homologous structures to Bartholin's glands in females. Both glands are responsible for secreting mucus that lubricates the respective areas: Cowper's glands secrete into the urethra, while Bartholin's glands secrete into the vaginal orifice.

OPTION C: Skene's glands also known as the paraurethral glands, are located near the female urethra and are homologous to the prostate gland in males, not to the Bartholin's glands.

OPTION D: Prostate is a male accessory sex gland that contributes to semen production. The homologous structure in females would be Skene's glands, not Bartholin's glands.

Type: Must know

Topic: Anatomy of female genital tract

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 17th edition, Page no. 15

questions.text: Peg cells are found in
questions.solution:
Peg cells are a component of the epithelial lining of the fallopian tubes, where they play a crucial role in reproductive physiology. They are specialized secretory cells that produce a fluid that nourishes and supports the egg and sperm during their journey through the fallopian tube. This fluid also helps in the transport of the egg and facilitates fertilization.



Fig: Histology of Fallopian tube

Ovary is lined by cuboidal epithelium.

Fallopian tube by ciliated columnar epithelium

Endocervix is lined by columnar epithelium

Ectocervix is lined by stratified squamous epithelium.

Type: Must know

Topic: Fallopian tube histology

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 17th edition, Page no. 22

choices.text: Equal incidence at all these sites

questions.text: Most common site for adenocarcinoma of cervix is:
questions.solution:
OPTION C: Adenocarcinoma of the cervix commonly arises from the glandular cells of the endocervix, which produce mucus. The endocervix contains columnar epithelium, making it the primary site for adenocarcinoma

OPTION A: Transformation zone is the most common site for squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, not adenocarcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma arises from the squamous epithelium that undergoes metaplasia in this zone.

OPTION B: Ectocervix is covered by squamous epithelium and is not the common site for adenocarcinoma, which arises from glandular cells.

OPTION D: Equal incidence at all these sites: This option is incorrect because adenocarcinoma predominantly arises from the glandular cells of the endocervix and not equally from all areas of the cervix.

Type: Must know

Topic: Adenocarcinoma of cervix

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Page no. 660-661

choices.text: Send To Lab At Room Temperature
Each Sample Weight should be Minimum 8 grams
Sample must reach Lab Within 48 Hrs

questions.text: A polio surveillance officer informed about suspected polio paralysis in his area. immediately rushed with his team and collected stool sample for investigation. All are true about collected stool sample except
questions.solution:
• Transporting stool samples for analysis
  • All children with acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) should be reported and tested for wild poliovirus within 48 hours of onset.
  • Because shedding of the virus is variable, two specimens taken 24-48 hours apart are required.
  • Highest concentrations of poliovirus in the stools of infected individuals are found during the first two weeks after onset of paralysis.
  • Sample volume: Each sample should be at least 8-10 grams.
  • Stool specimens have to be sealed in containers and stored immediately inside a refrigerator or packed between frozen ice packs at 4-8°C in a cold box. This is called as reverse cold chain.
  • Specimens should arrive at the laboratory within 72 hours of collection.
  • Undue delays or prolonged exposure to heat on the way to the laboratory may destroy the virus 

Mnemonic for ease of remembrance-

FITS

  • Find: Find and report children with AFP.
  • Investigate: Transport stool samples for analysis.
  • Target: Isolate poliovirus.
  • Survey: Map the virus.

questions.text: A 17 year old male patient presented to ENT OPD with the history of nasal obstruction and severe nasal bleeding. The nasal endoscopy picture shows a mass in the choana as given in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a highly vascular tumor typically seen in adolescent males (often around the age of 15-25 years). It is known for causing symptoms like nasal obstruction, epistaxis and may extend into the nasopharynx or choana. The tumor's highly vascular nature often leads to significant bleeding, which is a distinguishing feature of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

other options:

  • Inverted Papilloma: This is a benign but locally aggressive tumor, usually presenting in middle-aged (40+)adults. It is less likely in a 17-year-old and generally does not cause significant bleeding.
  • Antrochoanal Polyp: This is a benign polyp originating from the maxillary sinus and typically presents with nasal obstruction, but it is not typically associated with severe bleeding.
  • Rhinosporidiosis: This fungal infection can present with nasal masses and bleeding, but it is more common in certain geographic regions (like India) and would usually show characteristic features on histopathology

questions.text: What is the action of marked muscle in the given image?
questions.solution:
The marked muscle in given image is Flexor carpi ulnaris.



Origin - medial epicondyle, olecranon and posterior portions of ulna

Insertion - pisiform, hook of hamate and base of 5th metacarpal bone

Action - flexion and addiction of wrist



Option wise explanation:

Option B: Flexion and abduction of wrist: by Flexor carpi radialis.

Option C: Extension and adduction of wrist: Extensor carpi ulnaris.

Option D: Extension and abduction of wrist: Extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis.

questions.text: Patient presents with fever for 3 weeks and abdominal distension. antibiotics and anti-malarial treatment not helpful. The patient is tested with rk39 dipstick which is positive. The drug of choice will be?
questions.solution:
• The leishmaniasis are a group of parasitic diseases caused by protozoa of the genus Leishmania, transmitted by the bite of a
  • Single or multiple lesions on the uncovered parts of the body: an erythematous papule begins at the sandfly bite, enlarges to a nodule and extends in surface and depth to form a scabbed ulcer. Ulcers are painless, unless there is secondary bacterial or fungal infection.
    Usually, lesions heal spontaneously, leaving a scar, and result in lifelong protection from disease. Lesions may also spread to the mucosa (mouth, nose, conjunctiva) giving rise to the mucocutaneous form, which may cause severe disfigurement.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: identification of Giemsa-stained parasites in smears of splenic, bone marrow, or lymph node aspiration-biopsy. Splenic aspiration is the most sensitive technique but carries a theoretical risk of potentially fatal haemorrhage.
  • Serological diagnosis: rK39 dipstick test and direct agglutination test (DAT) can be used for diagnosis of primary visceral leishmaniasis in clinically suspect cases. Diagnosis of relapse is only by parasitological confirmation.

Visceral leishmaniasis

  • First-line treatment: a pentavalent antimonialIM or slow IV: 20 mg/kg daily for 17 days + paromomycin IM: 15 mg (11 mg base)/kg daily for 17 days.
  • Second-line treatment for relapse and for specific vulnerable groups: severe disease, pregnant women, patients over 45 years:
    liposomal amphotericin BIV infusion: 3 to 5 mg/kg once daily for 6 to 10 days up to a total dose of 30 mg/kg
  • Treatment in HIV co-infected patients:

liposomal amphotericin BIV infusion: 3 to 5 mg/kg once daily for 6 to 10 days up to a total dose of 30 mg/kg

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K. Park, 27th Edition, Page no.351-3

questions.text: Identify the above logo & select correct option for Composition of food under given program.
questions.solution:
• Mid-Day Meal Scheme was started in India from 15th August 1995 under the name of 'National Programme of Nutritional Support to Primary Education (NP-NSPE)'. In October 2007, NP-NSPE was renamed as 'National Programme of Mid-Day Meal in Schools', which is popularly known as Mid-Day Meal Scheme. Given under ICDS

  • Beneficiaries of ICDS
    • 300 feeding days in a year
    • Should meet 1/3rd of calorie and 1½ protein
  • Revised norms
    • 1 AWC for 400-800 population
    • 2 AWC for 800-1600 population
    • 3 AWC for 1600-2400
  • In September 2021, the Mid-Day Meal Scheme was renamed 'PM POSHAN' or Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman. PM POSHAN will extend the hot cooked meals to students studying in pre-primary levels or Bal Vatikas of government and government-aided primary schools, in addition to those already covered under the mid-day scheme.
  • In formulating mid-day meals for school children, the following broad principles should be kept in mind-

(a) the meal should be a supplement and not a substitute to the home diet;

(b) the meal should supply at least one-third of the total energy requirement, and half of the protein needs.

(c) the cost of the meal should be reasonably low;

(d) the meal should be such that it can be prepared easily in schools; no complicated cooking process should be involved;

(e) as far as possible, locally available foods should be used; this will reduce the cost of the meal; and

(f) the menu should be frequently changed to avoid monotony.

TIPS AND TRICKS

SENSE-C

  • Supplement: The meal should be a supplement and not a substitute to the home diet.
  • Energy & Protein: The meal should supply at least one-third of the total energy requirement and half of the protein need.
  • Not expensive: The cost of the meal should be reasonably low.
  • Simple preparation: The meal should be such that it can be prepared easily in schools; no complicated cooking process should be involved.
  • Eat local: As far as possible, locally available foods should be used; this will reduce the cost of the meal.
  • Change frequently: The menu should be frequently changed to avoid monotony.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Under the Mid Day Meal Scheme) the meal should supply at least one-third of the total energy requirement, and half of the protein needs

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K. park, 27th Edition, Page no. 776
