questions.text: A child Presented with multiple fragile bone also known as Brittle Bone Disease. On Examination, Child has thin transparent sclera which appears blue. He had mutation in COLIA1 gene. Identify the most common inheritance of disorder from which child is suffering.
questions.solution:
Child is suffering from Collagen vascular Disease - Osteogenesis Imperfecta.

Characteristic Symptoms and signs of disease includes

  • Multiple Fragile bones,
  • Joint Hypermobility and
  • Blue sclera

COLIA1 or COLIA2 Gene mutation. Most commonly it is autosomal dominant.

  • Types I to IV are caused by mutations in the COL1A1 orCOL1A2 genes or both.
  • Type I is mild, but type II is severe and infants born with the condition usually not survive,
  • types III and IV are progressive and/or deforming.
  • Mutation results into replacement of Glycine affecting formation of Tripple Helix, decreased expression of Collagen, Structurally abnormal, weakening of Bone, enzymatic Degradation called as Procollagen Suicide.

Collagen Vascular Diseases having Autosomal Dominant inheritance includes

  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta,
  • Marfan's Syndrome,
  • Ehler Danlos Syndrome.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter 50 Page no. 614

questions.text: What is the most common source of bleeding during tonsillectomy
questions.solution:
The main venous drainage of tonsil is paratonsillar vein which lies on the bed of tonsil along with superior constrictor muscle, and it is the main source of bleeding in tonsillectomy.

The main arterial supply of tonsil is tonsillar branch of facial artery.

The conventional method of tonsillectomy is dissection and snare method.

Primary haemorrhage: Occurs at the time of operation. It can be controlled by pressure, ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

Reactionary haemorrhage: Occurs within a period of 24 h and can be controlled by simple measures such as removal of the clot, application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.

Secondary (delayed)haemorrhage. Usually seen between the fifth to tenth postoperative day. It is the result of sepsis and premature separation of the membrane. Usually, it is heralded by bloodstained sputum but may be profuse.

Reference: P L Dhingra ENT seventh edition page no 489

• Pseudoexfoliation glaucoma is a condition where pseudoexfoliative material (a flaky, fibrillary material) accumulates on the lens capsule. This material can lead to mechanical obstruction of the outflow of aqueous humor, causing elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) and glaucoma.
  • The lens capsule in pseudoexfoliation can show characteristic exfoliative deposits that can be seen during slit-lamp examination, particularly around the anterior lens capsule, which is a hallmark feature of this condition

questions.text: A neonate presents with colicky pain and vomiting with sausage-shaped lump in the abdomen, diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
This question shows a typical case scenario comprising of a neonate who has presented with colicky abdominal pain and vomiting with sausage shaped lump in the abdomen. This case scenario is diagnostic of intussusception.

Option A is not the answer because enterocolitis tends to present with diarrhoea and abdominal pain.

Option B is not the answer as if the patient would have perforation of the abdomen he would have come to you with distended abdomen rather than sausage shaped lump.

Option D is not the answer as appendicitis typically presents as a pain in right iliac fossa.

choices.text: Fallen leaf sign - Aneurysmal bone cyst
Fallen leaf sign - Simple bone cyst

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with pain in the arm. An x-ray is shown in the image below. What is the sign and diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A simple bone cyst (also known as a unicameral bone cyst or solitary bone cyst) is a benign, fluid-filled bone lesion that typically occurs in the long bones, most commonly in the proximal humerus or femur. It is most often seen in children and adolescents, especially between the ages of 5 and 15.

Location: Usually in the metaphysis of long bones (especially the proximal humerus or femur), but can occasionally occur in other bones.

Radiographic Appearance:

  • Appears as a well-defined, lytic (radiolucent) lesion with a thin sclerotic border.
  • It is centrally located within the bone.
  • The cyst is usually unilocular (single cavity), although in some cases, it may appear multilocular due to trabeculations or septations.

The fallen leaf sign is a classic radiological feature associated with a simple bone cyst, particularly after a pathological fracture. When a bone cyst is fractured, fragments of the cyst’s inner lining (cortical bone) or bony fragments from the fracture fall into the fluid-filled cavity. On X-rays, these fragments appear as radio-dense (bone-like) structures lying at the bottom of the cyst, resembling a "fallen leaf."

Incorrect Options -

Option A: Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC) is a benign, but locally aggressive bone lesion characterized by blood-filled cavities separated by connective tissue septa. It typically affects young individuals (under 20 years of age) and can occur in any bone, though it's most commonly found in the long bones (such as the femur and tibia), vertebrae, or pelvis

Option C: Osteosarcoma arises from mesenchymal cells that produce osteoid or immature bone. It most commonly occurs in the metaphysis of long bones, especially around the knee (distal femur, proximal tibia), but can affect any bone. It shows Sunburst appearance and codman's triangle.

Option D: Chondrosarcoma is a malignant cartilage-producing tumor, typically treated with surgical excision.

X-ray: Shows lytic lesions with "popcorn" or "ring-and-arc" calcifications.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: A Simple bone cyst (also known as a unicameral bone cyst or solitary bone cyst) is a benign, fluid-filled bone lesion that typically occurs in the long bones

Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, A Textbook of Medical Imaging, seventh edition Page no 1034

questions.text: What is the name of the instrument in the following image?
questions.solution:
Thermoluminescent dosimeter (TLD) is a passive radiation detection device that is used for personal dose monitoring or to measure patient dose.

When the radiation falls on TLD, the electrons are excited and store energy. After a varied period (can be one month, bimonthly, quarterly or even biannual), the TLD badges are sent for reading.

Incorrect Options -B, C and D.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Thermoluminescent dosimeter (TLD) is a passive radiation detection device that is used for personal dose monitoring or to measure patient dose

Reference: Christensen’s Physics of diagnostic radiology, second edition, page no 132

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida requires pain relief for the second stage of labor. The obstetrician decides to perform the procedure shown in the image. Which anatomical landmark is used as a guide in this nerve block?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a PUDENDAL NERVE BLOCK and ischial spine is the landmark for pudendal nerve.

OPTION A: Pubic symphysis: It is not used as a landmark for the pudendal nerve block. It is a landmark for different procedures like abdominal incision placement in C-section, Symphysiotomy etc.

OPTION B: Ischial tuberosity: It is not the primary landmark for the pudendal block. The block targets the area near the ischial spine.

OPTION C: Ischial spine: The pudendal nerve block is performed by targeting the area near the ischial spine, which is a key landmark for the procedure.

OPTION D: Sacral promontory: It is used as a landmark for other procedures like laparoscopic pelvic surgeries, sacral nerve stimulation etc. but not for the pudendal nerve block.

Type: Must know

Topic: Obstetric analgesia

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Page no. 1206-1207

questions.text: Atrioventricular bundle connects the SA node to AV node via inter nodal tract. Thorel tract in the bundle is
questions.solution:
• In human heart SA node is the pacemaker of the heart. Impulse from SA node is spread through the heart via various tracts.
  • Among this atrioventricular bundle connects the SA node to AV node. It spreads the impulse to the both atrias.
  • This bundle is divided into three branches. They contain purkinje fibers.

Anterior, middle and posterior tracts.

  • Option c: Posterior tract is called as tract of Thorel.
  • Option b: Middle bundle of tract is known as Wenckebach tract.
  • Option a and Option d: Branch of the anterior internodal tract that connects the right and left atria is Bachmann bundle.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page no.1180

choices.text: Obtain a complete blood count and differential
Place the infant under a warmer

questions.text: An infant weighing 1200 g is born at 32 weeks' gestation. Initial evaluation was normal and the infant was transferred to the level 2 nursery for prematurity. The nurse there calls at 1 hour of life and reports the infant is tachypneic. Vital signs include a heart rate of 140 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 80 breaths per minute, a temperature of 35°C (95°F) and peripheral oxygen saturation of 98%. The lungs are clear with bilateral breath sounds and there is no murmur, the infant is in no distress. The child's chest radiograph is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating the infant?
questions.solution:
• The radiograph is normal. However, the case describes a cold infant.
  • A room temperature of 24°C (approximately 75°F) provides a cold environment for newborn infants. Aside from the fact that these infants emerge from a warm, 37.6°C (99.5°F) intrauterine environment, at birth, infants (and especially preterm infants) are wet, have a relatively large surface area for their weight, and have little subcutaneous fat.
  • Within minutes of delivery, the infants are likely to become pale or blue and their body temperatures will drop. In order to bring body temperature back to normal, they must increase their metabolic rate; ventilation, in turn, must increase proportionally to ensure an adequate oxygen supply.
  • Because a preterm infant is likely to have respiratory problems and be unable to oxygenate adequately, lactate can accumulate and lead to a metabolic acidosis. Infants rarely shiver in response to a need to increase heat production.
  • If the tachypnea persists after warming the infant, sepsis, pneumonia, and primary surfactant deficiency are all possible; thus, several of the alternative answers then may be appropriate.

Reference: Cloherty & Stark's manual of neonatal care, 8th ed., pg. 187
